With its compact and sleek looking, the KRUPS electric coffee grinder makes a convenient and useful addition to any kitchen.
For safety, the blades do not spin unless the lid is securely placed.

reviews.reviewText:
I need to add to my previous review because the situation has gone from bad to worse. I reached out to KRUPS who asked me to send the product back since it was still within the warranty period. I returned the product 2 weeks ago; today, I received an email from customer service indicating that it will take 2-3 weeks to determine if the product is repairable. If not, I might (not, I will) get a new grind/ brew coffee maker. This is nonsense. Not waiting a month for a crappy coffeemaker. I purchased a Cuisinart. I have had Cuisinart grind/brew before, they break after 2-3 years, but at least it’s not within 2-3 months, like Krups. Don’t buy this product. Bad product, bad service.

Less than 6 months after I purchased this product, the grinder stopped working. I looked for online fixes but Krupp’s uses a triangle shaped screw so I can’t open the unit to attempt to fix using online instructions. The user manual does not address how to fix grinder problems which apparently is something that happens often shortly after the warranty expires. I bought a Krupp’s thinking this was going to be a quality product - apparently I was wrong. I’m going to try calling Krupp’s in hopes they will replace.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's probably best to have one for coffee and one for Spices
reviews.reviewText:
It's probably best to have one for coffee and one for Spices. B/c you don't want your coffee to taste like your spices. It's a little cumbersome to clean thoroughly. Even if you do, it still smells a bit like stale coffee (or spices). But for the price, it does the job extremely well. I've found that for coffee you can get coarse-ground with a 5-second solid push of the on button. Medium ground (my preference) for a 12 second press. And very find powder for a 20 second press. Pro-tip: Gently/slowly Shake the grinder while it's grinding to help make a more consistent grind, otherwise you end up with a mix of fine and coarsely ground particles.

An absolute must for anyone that enjoys freshly ground "whole-bean" coffee made in a French Press! (compare to any chain coffee shop, you will never go back!)

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinder in itself is good and powerful but there is something fundamentally wrong with ...
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this coffee grinder trusting the 1000+ review on Amazon. The grinder in itself is good and powerful but there is something fundamentally wrong with the design. My opinions are based on the comparison of this grinder v/s the Mr. Coffee Blade Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System (I owned this one for nearly four years)

a. Both grinders are fairly powerful and do the basic job well which is grinding the coffe beans.
b. Mr. Coffee has some additional settings in terms of desired coarseness, cup size of the beans which is missing from the KRUPS grinder. In all honesty, I never used the feature in Mr. Coffee and mostly judged the coarseness by eye.
c. The most important distinction which made me dislike the product is that this is horrible design if you want to store the coffee beans for later use. As soon as you open up this grinder, closing the lid back with coffee still inside locks the lid in place and makes it really hard to remove it the next time around. I have spilt a lot of coffee grind trying to do this. The only workaround is to consume the coffee at once after grinding or store it another container.
d. This design also makes it difficult to clean the grinder. With Mr. Coffee the top was separated from the motor and was dishwasher safe.

3/5 for inherently bad design.

This is an inferior version of a Krups grinder even though it says "KRUPS". This grinder did NOT grind the coffee grounds evenly and left big chunks of the beans (of all places) on the bottom of the grinder, even though I was only grinding for 2 cups of coffee and I did not overfill the grinder in any way. Also, the cord was extremely short and much shorter than my current Krups grinder. I have been using Krups grinders for more than 15 years and was hugely disappointed - I feel ripped off and have arranged to return the grinder. Will not buy this product online again.

reviews.reviewTitle: maybe a total of 20 times to grind several tablespoons of things like cumin seed
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this just over two years ago (there goes the warranty) for use as a spice grinder. It was used very sporadically, maybe a total of 20 times to grind several tablespoons of things like cumin seed. Long story short, it burned out. I'm talking, heat, burned electronics smell, smoke. I imagine it would have failed sooner, but I didn't use it enough.

Terrible quality.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... been a 5 star review had the machine been better at regulating the strength of the coffee and had ...
reviews.reviewText:
This would have been a 5 star review had the machine been better at regulating the strength of the coffee and had a larger pot. I may be the reluctant "Queen" of grind and brew machines. I have had quite a few in search of everything I want: ease of use, control of strength, little or no maintenance, easy clean, large pot, and a heater plate. I have tried Cuisinart (several makes - about 3 different ones), Kenmore, Breville, Capresso, and Gourmia. In my quest for a decent grind and brew, I found many were quite flawed because they broke or jammed easily, they were hard to clean and required in depth cleaning often, or were cheaply made with inferior plastic parts. So when my most recent machine (a high end Breville) started to to go after just 9 mos of ownership, I was exasperated. I was tired of searching for what didn't seem to exist, and for paying big $ for poorly engineered machines. Yet I did not want to give up the grind and brew type because it makes the best coffee I believe. So I came across this Krups. I decided to chance it as I had not tried Krups yet.
When I received the machine, I quickly realized it is essentially a Capresso. However, it so far is not as persnickety as a Capresso and is much easier to clean and maintain. The coffee is great and the machine is easy to use. It keeps the pot hot for several hours - an important feature for me because the thermal higher end pots do not do this to my satisfaction. Plus they pour lousy. It is kinda loud while grinding, and it is a bit slow in making the coffee, but those are minor flaws I can easily live with. The biggest knock I have against the machine is how much beans it uses and how it does a poor job of regulating the strength of the coffee. On any setting or grind level the coffee comes out the same - strong. I like it that way, so I can deal, but I would prefer to have it work the way it is supposed to so I have control of flavor. I have had it for 1 week at this writing, so we shall see. I am glad I bought it so far. I hope it lasts a long time, and maybe when it dies there will be an improved version. For now it is the best I have found.

This was an absolute piece of trash. It worked for two days, and it was great. Then it died unceremoniously, making noise but not grinding, then brewing hot water. I did the troubleshooting that was recommended, quadruple checked that I was going through the correct steps and using it properly, and it still did not work. I am extremely disappointed, and based on the reviews of other buyers who had the same experience, opted for a return and refund rather than a replacement. What an absolutely garbage product. So annoyed.

This grinder doesn't provide preset grinding levels- you have to determine the grind yourself and stop it when you think it's done (which is difficult to see without stopping it and taking the cover off). This is not a product for a coffee bean grinding novice, who is just trying to make some coffee. I've tried grinding less (and ended up with a course grind that didn't work well), and I've grinded too long (where I ended up with coffee dust), and I'm just wasting my beans and time. I purchased this because America's Test Kitchen recommended it (this is the last time I trust them). I'm going to just replace the inexpensive grinder I had for years, that served me well, and determined my grind by the number of cups I needed and let me select the grind I wanted (course, drip, or espresso). I'd bet this is a good product, it's just not great for someone who doesn't know the best grind by sight.

Note: I added label pics because someone asked about voltage

He works so hard for such a little guy. I use my Krups grinder for grinding spices and coffee (I go through with a chopstick to loosen up the stragglers hanging on to the edge of the walls and also grind a piece of bread that cleans up the smells and excess grindings handing about.)

That being said I find it great for people like me who just do single cups of coffee in a Kurig. It does blend a bit on the fine side, so sometimes you need to like the custom cups with a little paper to prevent sludge from happening.

It's a great blender for the price and it's size, definitely!

reviews.reviewTitle: WARNING SMOKE COMING OUT OF GRINDER AFTER 3 NORMAL USES.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder has been a very big disappointment. It must be a situation where you get what you pay for. The worst thing about this grinder is how great it could be despite this major flaw, of it apparently overheating randomly and smoke exiting from where the power cable goes into the casing! The strong smell of burning electricity and smoke exiting this grinder negates all the pros which are: a very affordable price at less than 20 dollars. small design which fits well in the kitchen, fast grinded java beans for a quick morning espresso, easy to clean steel blade. However the benefit of having fresh ground espresso coffee at an affordable price is negated when the smell of burning electricity/ plastic and smoke start filling your kitchen really starts the day on the wrong foot and presents a safety issue. Maybe this one unit is defective, I have contacted the company and had no response yet, but this is my first time using a KRUPS grinder and if it isn't just the case of one defective unit then I cant recommend them. If it proven to me that it was just one defective unit I will remove this review.

I had the older version of this Krups Grind and Brew. It made the perfect cup of coffee every time! I was crushed when it finally didn't work anymore, but elated to find the new model here on Amazon. It's even better than the original model. Amazon always has what I need, carrying quality product lines for the best prices. My Krups arrived as promised in excellent condition. LOVE THIS PRODUCT!

Update: I absolutely hate this grinder. It's messy and a pain to use.

This isn't exactly what I thought it was going to be. I watched many videos on coffee grinders and this was my 2nd choice I ordered this instead of my 1st choice by mistake. Anyways, it's a bit messy and I don't like having to lift the whole thing up to dump out. It works and you just hold the button down till your beans are ground up. You have to play around with it to know how many seconds to hold down. It's small and compact and looks nice on the coffee cart.

I dread using this grinder in the morning. The cord is so frustratingly short and not even the width of my kitchen counter. I need to use and extension cord.. The grinding is so-so with large pieces mixed in with the fine grounds. The MOST irritating feature is the choice of materials. The cover and cavity build up a very strong static charge which means that the grounds stick to the grinder. You can't tap them out, you need a brush. I can't grind coffee without making a mess. (edit 1-25-19) In the dry winter air here in the desert, I find that the static charge is so strong that coffee -powder leaps from the grinder and goes everywhere. I've changed my rating to 1 star and tossed the grinder. -

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent grind & brews machines hard to find
reviews.reviewText:
I did a lot of research on grind & brew machines (Capresso, Cuisinart, DeLonghi, Krups, Kenmore) that weren't a few hundred dollars (Breville) before buying the Krups. Background: I had a Cuisinart grind & brew (DGB550) for 6 years before the filter basket started popping off whenever I used whole beans (vibrations from grinder), which spilled coffee & grinds all over the countertop and in the machine. I had taken for granted the need to wash (not just a quick rinse) the grinder+lid, filter basket+lid, and carafe every single time we used the machine. I was thus determined to find a grind & brew that made decent fresh coffee, wasn't a pain to clean, and didn't cost an arm and a leg.

I've had the Krups for 2 months now and overall it's great. I had to return the first one because every so often, it wouldn't start ... after speaking to Krups customer service, the only way was to go through a non-grind brew cycle, then the machine would essentially reset so that I could run a grind-brew cycle. Pretty sure it was a specific unit defect, haven't had the issue since I got it replaced with a new one.

The main complaints I saw on Krups reviews was that 1) some of the grinds were wasted during brewing because they would not be wet, 2) too many beans being used, 3) inconsistent brew strength, 4) loud when grinding, 5) small bean holder. Feedback: 1) whenever I brew, all the grinds are wet and level in the filter, so I haven't seen any issue. 2) I haven't found grinds hiding anywhere, so I'm not sure it's using significantly more beans than is needed to brew the coffee. 3) As long as the coffee isn't weak-tasting or super concentrated, I'm good with it. The coffee has tasted fine on all strength settings. 4) Yes, it's loud, but not any louder than my Cuisinart. Any mechanical grinding action is going to be loud unless it's encapsulated deeper into the machine or has additional barriers to reduce the sound transmission (I would assume more expensive machines may do that better, but not necessarily a primary consideration when designing a coffee maker. 5) We brew 5-6 cups (2 full big mugs) almost every day and have to refill the bean holder every few days ... for me, not too inconvenient.

Other observations: the carafe is a bit flimsy, especially the lid that flips open when you pour the coffee ... always have to remember to keep my thumb on the top; cleaning is easy as only the filter basket needs to be emptied and rinsed along with the carafe; the gold tone filter is common amongst most coffee machines and I've never found it to be effective (vs. paper filter). Overall I'm very happy with the Krups grind & brew.

reviews.reviewTitle: First Test - Toasted Sticky Rice Powder Khao khua (ข้าวคั่ว)
reviews.reviewText: Just got the grinder today and registered it with the manufacturer. As a first test, I ground some toasted sticky rice or glutenous rice (khao niew). After disinfecting the inside of the grinder, I put 2 ounces of the toasted sticky rice in the grinder and put the lid on. In under 15 seconds of pulsing the grinder, I had a very good medium fine grind of the now khao khua. Rice is pretty hard anyway and when it is toasted much of the water content evaporates leaving a very hard kernel. Traditionally, a pestle and mortar are used. With a little care and patience, the Krups grinder will not over heat the spices you grind if you take your time between pulses to keep the temperature down. I'll grind other whole spices as I need them and they will be much fresher than the pre-ground spices we buy. I was able to clean up the bladed part of the grinder using a dry paper towel and tapping the powder out, while rinsing the lid. All in all it worked fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: (it's easy to depress the activation button while handling the machine)
reviews.reviewText:
KRUPS F203 Electric Spice and Coffee Grinder with Stainless Steel Blades, 3-Ounce is NOT a burr type grinder!! I did not seek a burr grinder so this model fits my needs.
(1) It's rated at "3 ounce" which is not explained anywhere. Some mention should be made: to weigh 3 ounces of unground beans means having a suitable kitchen scale.
(2) The manufacturer tries to imbue this grinder with the mystique of accuracy and finesse. That's on them: this product is not "accurate" in the sense suggested by the manufacturer. IT JUST GRINDS AND DOES IT IN A FEW SECONDS. (how many seconds? they leave it to you to experiment!) And: the amount of ground coffee to water ratio is ridiculously small for the average coffee drinker. "7 grams of ground coffee per 5 oz. cup" is only 5/8 of AN ACTUAL 8-ounce cup.(and who in the United States bothers to use grams when our entire history is based on English Measures?)
(3) The one accurate thing in the packaged instructions: DISCONNECT the machine when not actually grinding! (it's easy to depress the activation button while handling the machine).
(4) Not "easy to clean." I use a brush about the size of a tooth brush then wipe clean with a damp sponge.

Anyone wanting more or better will have to pay more to get the coffee/spice grinder which meets their needs.

Not a good grinder at all! I get whole beans and powder in a grinding session.. I can never get an evenly dristrivuted grind! Therefore, when I make coffee with it I get a lot of coffee residue in my cup and feel like I drinking coffee paste when I get to the bottom. Also, it clogs the filter because the fine granules clog my filter up and yet their are still whole beans so it make for bitter coffee. I feel like putting the beans in a bag and hitting it with my rolling pin would do a better job. I am still using this grinder as I wanted to try and get use of this one to get some use out of it but definitely not happy with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds Great, but Lacks in Design!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this as a replacement for my Kitchen Aid grinder which we had used and abused for about 7 years. While this grinder grinds extremely well, it is not super user friendly.

The usability issues with the grinder are in the design. To start with the top is angled which allows coffee grinds to spill out; if you turn the grinder over in an attempt to get the ground coffee into the lid you inevitably will still get coffee grounds on the counter. The second issue is the lack of measuring lines for whole bean coffee; perhaps, I was spoiled by the lines on the Kitchen Aid grinder but not having them makes the process of grinding enough coffee for a 12 cup pot of coffee harder. This actually leads to my third issue with the grinder, I can't fit enough beans for 12 cups of coffee like I could with my Kitchen Aid grinder; I have to grind the beans in two portions which increases the amount of coffee grounds that fall onto the counter.

While the product grinds coffee amazingly, its user friendliness leaves a lot to be desired.

This is a perfect little grinder. I use it to grind seeds (flax and chia) which it does quickly and well. The one asterisk is that if someone else is sleeping within audible range, the grinding does make a sharp noise. Maybe they should make a deluxe model with a muffler :). I had one of these for something like 20 years, and it still worked fine (only discarded it because it'd been so long since I'd used it that it was too tedious to clean). I have no reason to believe this one won't last as long.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent Reliable Choice for Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I like this coffee grinder above other styles I've used.
The grinder works very well and has consistently for a few years now.
This is my second one of this exact same style. I have a Jura Super Automatic coffee machine that grinds my beans internally so I gave my other one to a friend and just bought this exact same thing for replacement when I started back with my French Press for variety.
I like that it holds a proper amount of beans for my French Press or my Stovetop Espresso Maker.. on the Espresso pot I can grind beans 1 time and get 3 pots out of it.
I also like that the top is large and after grinding you can flip it upside down and the ground coffee is now in the top as a 'cup' which is easier to pour into the coffee pot without making a mess.
It grinds well at various levels of coarseness, it is easily cleanable, the price is GREAT on here, and it has worked reliably for years.
I suppose the 'burr style' grinder is better for coffee flavor but I have never been able to tell any difference between the two.

We use this grinder daily for coffee beans. I have used it for grinding coriander seeds, and it did that just as well. It is a nice size, and looks good on the counter. It is easy to use, and easy to clean. I actually can get most of the coffee grounds out just by brushing around with the edge of a plastic measuring spoon, since the grounds want to stick by static electricity after you run the grinder. But I have used the bread grinding trick before and after the coriander seeds, and it worked great. You may want to use a rubber gripper to pull the lid off, and unplug it before you do that, since the button to grind is on the lid. The rubber gripper will give you a lot more control easing that lid off slowly so you don't throw grounds all over the counter. This is about my favorite small appliance (in a close race with the toaster).

reviews.reviewTitle: Weak Coffee. Grind Function does not Work Well.
reviews.reviewText:
Update 1/21/19: Downgrading to 1 star because when I inadvertently dropped and broke my carafe and went to look for a replacement on the Krups website, I could not find it. I should have been able to search on this model, KM785D50, and get a list of accessories, but it is nowhere to be found. Krups should focus more on the customer experience. After much searching, I located the part on smallappliance.com but decided to purchase a different brand instead. So far, much happier with my choice. I hope this helps someone.

If you like a rich cup of freshly ground coffee, this is not for you. While the coffeemaker brews a good pot using already ground coffee, the grind function doesn't grind beans fine enough to make adequately strong coffee.

In order to brew coffee that is moderately strong, I have to first set the grinder to the most fine setting and ensure the coffee strength is set to Strong. Then I grind 10 cups, the max, and only pour in 7 cups of water. After the coffee is ground, I stop brewing, swing out the filter in order to even out the coffee since the machine grinds it into a ramp and some of the grounds are dry after brewing. I then close the filter door, set to Grind Off, and brew. Using a dark coffee, this will produce a rich cup. But, it is an incredibly manual process.

I will likely return this if possible to do so without the box.

Bottom Line: If you are okay with weak coffee, then this machine will suffice. I prefer a rich cup and will look to replace this with another coffeemaker that does a better job of grinding.

I just love this coffee grinder!
My boyfriend had the same one - he's had it for over 15 years and it still worked like a charm! that is, until the cleaning lady knocked it off the counter a couple of weeks ago and shattered the top into little pieces.

Anyway, the coffee grinder is perfect for my French press. You just put the coffee in, press the top, and voila.
The grind will be consistent as long as you don't overfill the grinder.
My French press is 16 ounces and I get the exact amount of coffee for 2 cups.

I haven't tried grinding spices yet but I'm sure it would work just fine. You can't really put the grinder in the dishwasher but I read somewhere that you can easily clean it with rice. You can wipe the interior with a wet cloth, dry it out, then grind some rice. The rice will soak up any residue of coffee or spices and will remove any lingering smell.

I read all the reviews and bought this machine because I need ultra finely ground coffee. Yes, this machine will do that, but:
1. The reservoir is very tiny. If you want to make a double or quad-shot latte, it won't hold enough.
2. The plastic lid fits way down INSIDE the reservoir and is very snug and difficult to lift out. Be prepared to have very strong fingers. When the lid does come out, very fine coffee is pulled out with it. (Fine coffee sticks to plastic.) When I finally got the lid out, the coffee flew all over the counter, and because I had the silverware drawer partially open in front of me, I had coffee grounds in the drawer as well. What a mess - and I was even being extra careful!
3. Because of its oils, the finely ground coffee is very difficult to remove from around and under the blade. I turned it upside down and tapped it, but to no avail.

If you only want one serving of coarsely ground coffee, this would probably work. If you want finely ground coffee, you'll have a mess.
The good news is that it was only about $15.00.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder that works well for the cost. I have used it for flaxseed grinding only so far.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this grinder for flaxseed, because I wanted fresher, whole kernel flaxseed that I could eat 1 oz daily for health reasons. This grinder was low-cost, but works well for creating perfectly ground flaxseed for my breakfast. I have ground up to 5.5 oz of flaxseed in the grinder to test how much I would be able to grind in it, and it has done a great job whether I use 1 oz or 5.5 oz.

I have not tried to grind coffee beans, since I mainly purchased the grinder for flaxseed.

For cleanup, the grinder does have the flaxseed slightly stick to the blade, so cleanup takes a bit longer than it would if the parts could all be removed (if they can, I haven't figured out how to do that anyway). This is a small issue, and I'm very pleased with this purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bad luck with my two grinders!
reviews.reviewText:
I have bought two of these from Amazon. I am not blaming Amazon for the quality but the first one last less than one year and the second one lasted about three months. I grind both coffee and flax seeds so maybe the seeds are eventually too much for it and it would last longer if only grinding coffee.
In fairness to the company I must say that I have not tried to get warranty service on either one because I am located in the Philippines and shipping stuff around is just not worth it for me rather than buying another one or a different product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does just one thing, but does it well!
reviews.reviewText:
Okay, this is a simple machine, and it does just ONE THING, but OMG it does it well. I actually have two of these grinders: one for spices, and another one for coffee beans. I’ve used them every day or multiple times a day for years, and they just keep on ticking.

Just put your whole spices in with the blades, put the lid on, and press down on the button until the spices are ground to your liking. I typically pulse the motor instead of running it constantly — a long run tends to make it heat up a bit. After dumping the ground spices out, a couple swipes with my finger around the grinding bowl will dislodge most of the stray spices. After I’m done, I hand-wash the lid and wipe down the bowl with a damp paper towel, then let it dry or hurry it up myself with a dry paper towel, and it’s ready to go again. I store it with the lid off so the bowl and lid stay very dry, which minimizes spice clumping.

I’ve had my grinders for years and used them frequently and they’re still going strong. I’d buy another one in an instant if something happened to mine. In fact, I’ve bought several more and given them away to family members who've expressed an interest in grinding their own spices.

A word of caution about cleaning: Do not put water into the bowl where the blades are. This should be elementary, but a couple years ago I got annoyed with swiping the bowl with a damp paper towel to clean it because no matter how hard I tried there was always a bit of spice left behind around the blade shaft, under the blades, or along the seam between the metal bowl and plastic side. So I started sloshing a liiiittle water in there, maybe a couple tablespoons, and was gratified to see the bowl nice and clean… but a couple days later the motor started to sputter. It sounded terrible and I was afraid my beloved spice grinder was going to die. I was so worried, in fact, that I bought another one from Amazon so I wouldn't be without my grinder for even a single day. Then I made the connection with the water. I stopped sloshing water in there, and after a couple days to dry out the spice grinder was working perfectly again and has worked fine ever since (that was two years ago). And the extra grinder? I gave it to another family member who wanted to grind her own spices.

I’ve also tried cleaning it by whizzing a couple teaspoons of dry rice in there, which worked okay but was kind of a hassle, so I just use the damp paper towel and am no longer concerned if a little spice is left behind. I use the grinder for cumin, coriander, and sometimes other savory spices like allspice, fennel seed, white peppercorns etc., which all taste good together, so I am no longer bothered by having a little bit of spice residue in my grinder. If I grind something unusual, which might affect the taste of the next dish I made, I clean the grinder out much more carefully, but still with a damp paper towel: I fold it a couple times and run the corner along the seam, then run a strip of paper towel under the blades, and so forth.

Seeing that I'm the first person to write a review I'm honored. Silent should be the first word in the description of this "Krups GX332850 Vortex Coffee, Spice Dry Herbs, Silent Grinder, 4.33 X 4.02 X 8.46 In, Silver". It's really amazing how quiet it really is. Its ability to grind coffee perfectly in a matter of 15 seconds. Compared to 1 minute with other grinders. The benefits of grinding coffee so quickly is it does not heat the beans up. Virtually no friction whatsoever. I'm enjoying the best cup of coffee I've had in a long time because of this thank you KRUPS. Thank you Amazon for sharing this great product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes Best pot of coffee but Error in instruction Book for using already ground beans
reviews.reviewText:
Updated 05/22/2019
Makes the best pot of coffee of all the grind-and-brews...but not without pain and misery. Must add this final note to our comments. The grinder just died. Arrrgh! Less than 2 years of use. Call us suckers, we just ordered another! It makes the BEST pot of coffee!

Updated 11/14/2017
I really wanted to love this Krups grind and brew. I have owned 6 (yes, six) of the older Krups Grind and Brew 7000 series. The coffee always tasted great in the 7000. But the more recent purchases of the 7000 did not work properly; they would grind but not drip the water through. So I looked to this newer version to have solved that problem.
So here comes the Krups KM785D50 today. For the first pot, one is supposed to brew 10 cups of clear water using the “Grind Off” function. The purpose of the “Grind Off” function is to be able to brew a pot of coffee with already-ground coffee. (Never put already-ground coffee through this burr grinder.). Turned it on...? Same problem as the 7000... no water processed. Did not even turn on the unit!!! ARRRRGGHH!
I was able to brew a pot of coffee by using the “grind and brew” function and it behaved well.
After calling customer service at Krups, we discovered an omission of a very important step in the instruction booklet.

So here is how it should read, and note I am paraphrasing, new instruction in all caps...

To brew with already ground beans, put in the desired amount of water. Put into the filter basket the desired amount of ground coffee. Be sure carafe is in place. Make sure your LED screen is activated, showing a blue color by pressing any button. Press “Grind Off” button once, a light will come on that switch. NOW PRESS THE “GRIND/BREW” SWITCH ONCE. A LIGHT WILL COME ON AT THAT SWITCH. AFTER A CONSIDERABLE PAUSE, WATER WILL BEGIN TO FLOW INTO THE FILTER BASKET.
Success finally!

This Krups coffee maker produces terrific tasting coffee with freshly ground beans.

I also tried the Capresso CoffeeTEAM #464. It is nearly identical as the Krups - same functions, pot, filter, etc. although has a more flimsy feel to it. The difference is, the Capresso coffee doesn’t taste as good. Maybe because the water does not flow over all the grounds. Every pot, some are left dry.

So I am back to my Krups KM785D50 and its delicious tasting coffee. It played hard to get, but we fell in love after all that!

I absolutely love this little grinder. I don't use it for coffee. I got it to grind up bread crumbs, herbs, seeds, nuts, and grains, and it works superbly for all of these. More than that, it is fun to use. It has a relatively quiet action, compared to a blender, and there is a terrific safety feature. You start it via a push button on the top of the lid. Thus, there is absolutely no way you can accidentally start the blades while your fingers are inside the little canister removing what you have ground.

This grinder has a sleek, modern design that is quite attractive. It comes in black, which fits in with any decor. It is easy to wash, but it must be done by hand, and the motorized bottom of the grinder must not be immersed in water. Do NOT put it in the dishwasher.

I've attached pictures of some of the things I have ground up. The first picture is whole cloves and fennel. The second picture is raw flax seeds. The third picture is toasted bread crumbs.

I cannot praise this little appliance highly enough, and I have no hesitation recommending it to family and friends. In fact, I am very likely to give it to some of them for Christmas.

Update December 30, 2016: I highly recommend that you get the extended warranty on this product. In the months since I've owned this product, I have had to have it replaced two times, because two different grinders simply stopped working. With the warranty, Amazon has instantly replaced the machine both times. I continue to love this grinder, but it does NOT last, and it is NOT worth buying without that warranty.

I bought this as an accessory to my Espresso maker, and the first two times I used this grinder, it actually produced a good grind, which resulted in great brew. The slightly awkward "Press & Hold" operation that involves the entire top of the grinder is not my favorite style, but it was serviceable. The third attempt to grind coffee resulted in the appliance locking up and producing a humming sound. After emptying the container and inspecting the grinder, I saw that the blades had a difficult time moving. They would move slightly and then stop, or with some coaxing, would move very slowly.
After gently wiping the inside and confirming that nothing was "tangled" in the spinning blade, I tried again with no success. I left the grinder alone for about an hour and when I picked it up again, it felt very warm at the bottom. I immediately unplugged it and haven't tried to use it since.
I concluded that the motor was either defective, or worse, the appliance has an electrical short which is preventing it from operating at full power. A short is especially dangerous because it can result in a significant FIRE HAZARD (hence being warm without being operated).
For the record, this grinder was well cared for, suffered no drops, impact damage, or liquid exposure.

Overall a very disappointing purchase. Next time I'll buy from a more established brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke within five uses, Do Not Buy!
reviews.reviewText: DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT. Krups is usually pretty reliable, but this order was processed and sold by Amazon. I used this no more than five times and the blade stopped turning completely. There is no way to open it up to fix it without potentially breaking the casing. I tried to return the item so that I would not need to leave a negative review, but Amazon won't allow returns after a certain amount of time.

reviews.reviewTitle: LISTEN TO OTHER REVIEWS!!! DO NOT BUY!!!!
reviews.reviewText: Used the machine for 60 days..The grinder started to sound different. Looked in the basket after realizing my cup of coffee was a bit weak. Hardly any grinds were in the basket. I am vigilante about cleaning the grinder, but I cleaned the grinder again. Next day, same thing. Not grinding properly. I moved the grind coarseness knob around, cleaned the shoot again, still not grinding properly. Called Amazon who called Krups. I got the same thing others got, we will send you a label, send it to us, we will analyze it to see if it warrants a replacement. BTW, do you use dark roast? We reccommend light or medium roast beans. WHAT??? Leni from Amazon stayed on the line, heard the whole conversation and arranged for me to send machine back to Amazon for a refund. Thought I would give Krups a try, I am going back to Cuisinart. At least I get 5 or so years out of that machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... coffee grinder for several months now and it is good. Not great
reviews.reviewText: I have had the KRUPS coffee grinder for several months now and it is good. Not great. I think there are a few things that would make it 5 stars and wanted to quickly list what I like and what I think could be improved. LIKE: 1) the resevour that holds coffee beans is adequately large (although slightly larger would have been nice. 2) I really like the shape and color. It is also light and compact. 3) The "button" is on top and allows for pulsing, which I use every time. All in all, it has all the features I wanted. There are a few things I think could be improved upon. DISLIKE: 1) The cord is pretty short. It is long enough for me but it seems it is only 2 feet or so and I am sure that might be an issue for many. 2) There is a clear plastic "lid" that you can remove to add coffee beans and this is actually my second grinder because somehow that got misplaced on my last one. Would be nice if there was something like a cord/wire or some other way to connect the top so it is not lost. Just my two cents.

I like being able to program the coffeemaker to start in the morning and I also enjoy the aroma and flavor of freshly ground coffee. I have used grind/brew coffeemakers for years, so when my old one quit working, it was time to replace it. This is my first experience with Krups, and so far I am very pleased.

The Krups KM785D50 is easy to program, makes good coffee, and is well priced for a grind/brew coffeemaker. While the grinding process makes a bit of noise, it is quieter than my previous machine. Face it, grinding hard coffee beans will make some noise, and since it is set to come on right before my alarm, it's not a problem for me. It can also be programmed to use ground coffee. Brewing is fairly quick, and taste is good. There are adjustments for number of cups from 2-10 and strength of brew, mild to strong, which are relatively easy to understand and program.

Among the many choices of coffee devices, there are relatively few grind/brew coffeemakers to choose from, with some very expensive choices. I have had units at many price points, the Krups KM785D50 is a good balance of features and price. I am glad I bought it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works beautifully if you know how to use it
reviews.reviewText:
I have had this coffee maker for one week, and so far so good! I was afraid it might be huge looking on my counter, based on the measurements, so I was pleasantly surprised by the compact size. I think the squarish shape attributes to that. This coffee maker is fairly new, so it isn't listed on the Krups website yet, and there's very little info available about it. Thanks to another reviewer on here, though, I had no trouble running my machine.

The initial cleaning process, as well as any cycle using already ground coffee, requires you to press not one, but TWO buttons. The GRIND OFF button, followed by the GRIND/BREW button. If you don't do this the machine won't run, and could appear not to work, because the instructions don't really go into the second step. To turn off the machine after brewing either method you must press the GRIND/BREW button again.

As far as quality, I was actually very impressed! Having upgraded from a very plasticy Mr. Coffee programmable machine, I thought this Krups (though also plastic) was much heavier duty, and more smartly designed. Time will tell as to how long it lasts, but so far it's gone above my expectations. I will be sure to update this review if there is any change.

I don't drink coffee - to me, this is a grinder for spices, usually pepper or cumin. I make my own spice mixes, and I like having access to fresh, whole spices in bulk. Grinding spices for spice mixes at the time you're making them ensures you're getting the best "bang for buck", and this grinder works great for that. Runs cool, even when you're reducing peppercorns to powder, and it's easy to get spices both in & out (and to see how things are going in the process.)

About the only thing I wish it could do was handle immersion in water - it can be a challenge to clean, especially because you want to clean it thoroughly between spices to avoid cross-contamination of oils & flavors. The container itself is great, but the base and motor can't be immersed so you really need to use a good, food-safe cleaner and a toothbrush to clean the blade and basin. But, given the performance and ease of everything else it does, I'm content with that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Highly recommended for a specific purpose
reviews.reviewText:
This is one of those products that fulfills a very specific need at a very low price. High five to Amazon and KRUPS. I owned a similar item years ago and the process for using it is so simple I didn’t even bother with the owners manual. I just this evening ground up small quantities of millet, buckwheat, brown rice and quinoa for a concoction I’m making. Almost effortless grinding and cleaning couldn’t be easier. Highly recommended for grinding small amounts of grains, spices, small nuts, dried chili etc.

***EDIT 8/23/19***
This grinder stopped working after three months. I contacted Amazon Cusuomer Support via their web page. I was referred to their chat app and I chatted with a Customer Service Rep for a good half hour. Plenty of “Thank you so much” and “Please hold” until - you guessed it - I was disconnected. I had provided my phone number but no one called me back. Rather than get angry I bought a Veken Coffee Grinder instead. Cost about the same and seems more substantial and durable.

First, the grinder clogs if you use French Roast. Okay, I got over that hurdle but then it just stopped working. Realized that there’s a “feature” that disables the coffee maker if you don’t descale it every 70 brew cycles. Okay, I got through that and then it just stopped working. I reached out to KRUPS who asked me to send the product back since it was still within the warranty period. I returned the product 2 weeks ago; today, I received an email from customer service indicating that it will take 2-3 weeks to determine if the product is repairable. If not, I might (not, I will) get a new grind/ brew coffee maker. Not waiting a month for a hunk of junk coffeemaker. Don’t buy this product. Bad product, bad service/warranty. Very disappointed in Krups.

Had 2 of previous models (over a period of many, many years) of grind and brew from Krups and were great, this one did not pump water to be able to brew with ground coffee from day one, kept it as we normally always use beans and grind, however after 4 days would not grind or pump the water at all. Very disappointed and returned for refund and will not purchase a grind and brew from Krups again. This model is not nearly as good as predecessor.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gets the job done, but difficult to clean and uneven grind size
reviews.reviewText:
This review is for the Krups electric blade (not burr) grinder.

I bought this grinder to use for medium-coarse grinds for a French press. It is LOUD. And I find that it grinds pretty unevenly, as you can see from my included photos - a few pulses lead to a combination of big chunks and fine powder. I tried shaking the grinder and flipping it upside down during use to better distribute the beans, but got the same result. When I made a cup of French press with it, I found that some of the smaller sediment was able to pass through the filter into my cup.

This grinder is also a bit difficult to keep clean:
-Lid: The bean dust coats the inside of the lid, which I wash out after use.
-Blade housing: The blade housing collects a lot of dust, so I’ll need to get a brush to sweep it out after each use - would have been nice if one was included.
-Outside and rim: The bean dust also clings to the outside of the grinder, and along the edges, making it difficult to close the lid again when the rim is covered in dust.

So overall, this is ok if you’re grinding for a drip coffee machine or just making the occasional cup like I do, but it's not so great if you’re a coffee connoisseur looking for an even, coarser grind or someone constantly changing beans who would want to clean it in between every use.

reviews.reviewTitle: know what you're getting into before buying
reviews.reviewText:
amazon tells me i bought this item Jan 2013. i clean it after every use and it is still going strong. this is good for someone who wants freshly ground beans for drip coffee in their machine at home or for grinding whole spices for cooking. it's also great for when you need to grind a bunch of beans to make your own cold brew. if you want to take it up a notch with your cup of joe, invest a real grinder where you can change the settings, because this won't suffice. there are some nice hand grinders that do a great job without the price tag of an automatic burr grinder

NB: i may also have an older version of this, not sure if it has changed but like i said above, it works well for my needs

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds coffee beans pretty well. A little loud
reviews.reviewText:
Grinds coffee beans pretty well. A little loud, I cant grind beans too early in the morning without waking up the wife.

For our drip coffee maker, it grinds the beans just right. To get a fine enough grind our espresso machine, it had to be run so long that it had a tendency to leave a layer on the bottom of the grinder that was too fine, really just a powder. I use it anyway, but I'm afraid its a fine enough powder that it may clog the espresso machine. In other words, the grind isn't perfectly consistent, but for the price this grinder does a good job.

reviews.reviewTitle: Came used and then broke after 2nd use
reviews.reviewText: The product came used and I know this because coffee beans came out once I opened the lid to the product. Despite it being used and returned to Amazon, I decided to keep the item anyways. Three days after using the item, I went to program the coffee maker and it crashed. It started to grind coffee beans then stopped and that was the end of that coffee maker. I unplugged the device, plugged it back in and troubleshooted the device in accordance to the manual and nothing. The only good thing out of this was that Amazon allowed me to return the device and was reimbursed a couple of days later. If you purchase this item, be careful.

1st: buyer beware! There's no real way to clean inside cup. So it’s best used for either coffee or spice, not both. I initially thought I would singularly use it, but that plan failed after a week or so. I then tried to rinse out. I don’t really think you’re supposed to do that. And the spices never really seem to come out. There's a lip that collects fine grind dust.
It’s also only good for 3 tablespoons, approx... when you start going over that, it gets messy. If you take the top lid off to look at the grind and then perhaps need to re-grind, it will get allover. No work around that. I considered buying a second one and labeling each: spice or coffee. Luckily before I could do that, I located an ingenious product replacement that solved all the problems and then some, for less than the cost of two: https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B07JGT63WJ/ref=ya_aw_od_pi?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This item was returned.

reviews.reviewTitle: works great! sure it has a mild smell of hot ...
reviews.reviewText: works great! sure it has a mild smell of hot plastic or glue if you keep it running for more than a few seconds. It's about the same smell as a new car. This is because you are not supposed to run it for more than a few seconds. As with any coffee grinder if you just run it for a long time the coffee just spins up around the edges. This is why it doesn't have an on switch it just has a button you must hold. If you press the button for 2 seconds then let go so it can stop all the coffee then falls to the bottom where the blades are, and repeat 8 times (at least when grinding four standard coffee scoops) it will be more finely ground than any pre-ground coffee I have ever bought. The whole process should take like 25 or 30 seconds. Not the several minutes that people whom complain say that grind for it just takes a little common sense.

I purchased my initial unit and upon its arrival became suspicious since there were residual coffee grounds in the grinding compartment. It appeared to have been previously used. When attempting to brew the initial batch it would not grind a sufficient quantity of beans to make a pot of coffee. The grinder seemed defective in that only a small amount of grounds were produced. After multiple attempts to operate I returned the unit to Amazon for a replacement. The second unit arrived and worked great for the first 3-4 pots of coffee. Then the second unit failed to initiate the grinding/brewing process following setup. There are obviously reliability problems with this unit.

This is a great basic grinder. Nothing fancy, just what I need every morning to make my coffee. It took a few tries to figure out how long to press to get coarse ground coffee for my French press.
A tip: after I grind coffee, I turn the grinder upsidedown and gently tap all around so the coffee falls inside the lid -- which I then use as a cup to remove the coffee. That's much easier than trying to get the ground coffee from around the blade. And to clean it, I just shake it gently over the sink and wipe it down with a dry cloth. I have only used this grinder for coffee, not sure how you can clean something else

Very happy with this grinder. If you are looking for a basic and sturdy appliance with an affordable price, give this a try!

For the most part, this grinder works exceptionally well: just a few quick bursts turns my whole beans into perfect, corse grounds for cold brewing. I'm not even concerned with the fact that its 3-ounce size is WAY too small for the amount of beans I need to grind in order to make cold brew. What really frustrates me—and is something I simply can't live with—is the mess that comes from using this appliance. As you can see in the product photo, the actual grinding vessel is very shallow in relation to the clear styrene reservoir, so the vast majority of the resulting grounds are contained in the reservoir. In the course of just a few quick bursts, the styrene protective cover builds up a huge static electric charge, which draws a substantial portion of the coffee grounds out of the reservoir when the grinder is opened, leaving a huge mess all over the outside of the appliance and the surrounding countertop (even worse when you have to do three or four separate grindings to make enough grounds for cold brew). I tried to minimize the mess by inverting the entire appliance when I opened it, but that wasn't any better... the combination of the static cling and the near-vacuum the reservoir creates causes grinds to explode all over the place. As far as I can tell, there's absolutely no way around losing a significant amount of grounds all over the counter. I strongly recommend finding an appliance with a better design for the grinding reservoir.

My last Krups lasted 4.5 years of daily use. This version:
-More attractive design
-No need for swing out basket while beans are being ground
-Not as cool to watch when the basket snapped into place, but less noise
-Could use some better instructions: takes a few seconds after pushing grind on button. two-hour heating plate option can't, as far as I tell, be reset (in the older one, I just hit no grind and reset it for two hours)
-Biggest complaint: getting right taste is trial and error, especially for lower cup variants (2, 4). I finally got it to a reasonable taste by selecting 6 cups to grind and adding filling to four and a half line.
-The lid on the water compartment has to be manipulated to stay shut, but doesn't affect the operations
-The permanent grounds basket (including in this new version) has a flat bottom rather than the v shape of the older maker. I don't know if that is a factor in the taste challenges, but it is easier to clean.
Once I figured out how to make a cup of coffee that tasted good, it seems to be working fine. If this one lasts four and a half years or longer, I likely will buy another Krups. And maybe the next version will be worth 5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor Customer Service for Replacement parts.
reviews.reviewText: I ordered this coffee maker in October 2017. Used it ~5 times -- worked very well. However, giving it a 1 star because after the 5th time I used it, I washed the coffee filter basket and the spring from the valve of the basket got caught on my dish cloth and pulled out of plastic casing (my fault). I could not figure out how to put it back together, so I ordered a new coffee filter basket with value on Jan. 8, 2018. It is now middle of May 2018, and still have not received the replacement filter basket! Checked on status in March, it was on back order from France with anticipated delivery 4/19.18.. Checked ~4/22/18...anticipated in 2 weeks. Checked on 5/1/18 -- now say "within 3 weeks"! This is through Small Appliance company which is referenced by Krups for re-order of parts. I never would have bought this machine if I knew of this poor customer service.

Pros: Powerful. High-capacity (more than 12 coffee measures). Fast.

Cons: Very noisy. Short power cord. Ground coffee cakes up in the bottom of the grinder. Does not come in white (anymore).

I used one of these (in white) for many years -- decades, actually -- before the little button in the top broke off. The new one seems to have been manufactured to a somewhat lower standard. The blade no longer has such a strong vortex, which was useful in cleaning the ground coffee out of the little basin under the blades. It is also noisier, perhaps a function of a more powerful, faster-spinning blade. I gave the old one five stars. The new one only gets four.

I'm still buying grinders. I hope the next will be the ~$100 Capressa(?) burr grinder, but I might settle for a cheaper major brand version like Cuisinart or whoever. I've had it with these slashers (blade grinders). Despite infinite patience with every technique possible, I just can't avoid the dust and big pieces. BTW, filling it sufficiently, say 2/3, and shaking slowly to force the grinds back down--jumpy suckers--seems to work best for me. There is no such thing as proper timing, because you just get more or less powder and chunks. If you're grinding coffee, it means you're buying the better stuff. So you may say you're not a coffee snob and it doesn't matter (join the other 2500 reviewers). Right. You also care about social issues more than bread & butter, too, don't you? Thumbing your nose at the problem is as good as fixing it, right? Now I'm about to cross the line, and it's just because of blade grinders. I'm sure you're all open-minded people. Sure you are. Let's just move on. I've got to bear with this &*%* thing a while longer, then I'm moving on for good to a proper burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gets the job done, but has some minor annoyances.
reviews.reviewText:
Have owned for about a year.

Gets the job done, but at what cost? It’s so loud!! high pitch noise when in use, making it more piercing than others (using the bodom grinder as comparison). Also, the ground coffee tends to stick to the bottom of the grinder requiring scraping out the bottom after a grind (I use my finger,hoping the blade doesn’t somehow start up!!! 😬)

Otherwise, grinds the coffee just fine. Build quality is fine - plastic feels a little “hard” so when I tap it to loosen the grounds it again has a very sharp sound; no damage to the grinder from doing that daily tho.

I used this grinder several times a week for 4 years. The motor is still going strong. The black outer casing cracked at the back before year 2 and it still functioned up until now. The lid has finally cracked and it’s become too hard to open and close it. For the price, I feel it’s done a great job. I’ve used it mainly for spices and occasionally coffee. I won’t be buying another one this time because I think it was a waste of resources that it only lasted 4 years. I’m going to upgrade and pay a little more for one that (I hope) will last a couple decades.

I'm a newer pour-over coffee drinker, so I suppose take this with a grain of salt since this would be my first time grinding my own beans. I got this over a more expensive burr grinder thinking it'd be a decent introduction and because the reviews were pretty positive. I tried the same tricks that some various YouTubers and articles have mentioned to get a consistent grind, but it just doesn't work. No matter what, I get lots and lots of powder and quite a bit of large chunks of bean. Definitely wouldn't recommend this even for someone just getting into making their own coffee.

Yeah, it will grind coffee. But the grind is so terribly inconsistent. Not satisfied at all, returning for a refund and getting a manual burr grinder. I tried several grinding techniques but still there is no consistency.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gets the Job Done, for the Most Part
reviews.reviewText:
This is not a bad grinder, but I imagine there are better out there. I use both the French Press and pour-over methods for making my coffee, each requiring a different grind. While this grinder does a fair job grinding my coffee finely, for my pour-over method, getting an even, coarse grind for my French press is next to impossible. Regardless of the amount of beans I place in the grinder, I can’t get any continuity in the grind. After many tries I’ve found a way to make it work, so I will continue to use it until I decide to pay more for a better grinder.

If you only want a fine grind for espresso, pour-over, or drip coffee, this will do just fine. However, if you are needing a coarse grind to be used in a French press, I’d say keep looking.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good All-Purpose Grinder. No Grind Control.
reviews.reviewText:
This spice grinder is pretty much the same exact design I had twenty-five years ago... I guess if it isn't broken, don't fix it. It chews boldly through coffee beans, rice, dried chilies... pretty much everything I've thrown at (into) it.
The one weakness is that the grind control is completely subjective by design; the user interface is pulse-only. If you care about consistency, pour through a wire screen to sift every few pulses and keep regrinding the chunky bits until they pass. Otherwise you get superfine powder with chunks in it.
The other thing to watch is that the stuff you're grinding into a fine powder works its way under the blade. It's not a problem functionally, but if you don't want your espresso to taste like paprika, make sure to clean it very carefully when you change over. Or maybe you like the serendipity... I don't judge.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to clean, grinds very nicely
reviews.reviewText:
It grinds very nicely, but it isn't perfectly even in doing so. I use it for coffee beans and this grinder rocks. I've seen this or a similar thing while watching the Great British Baking Show and I was mildly amused, that's an understatement.
Oils are easy to clean: just wipe the metal area inside with a paper towel and it's clean. For thorough cleaning I hand wash the cap or put it in the dishwasher if I need to use the machine, and I carefully wash the top by pouring water and hand wash it using sponge and diswashing liquid. It's easy not to hit water in the sensitive bottom part. Very good grinder.

Wow, what a bummer! My mom bought me a coffee grinder that ended up being messy and hard to clean. So I found this grinder on amazon last October and gave it a try. I’ve used it on and off to grind coffee beans. I clean it every time and generally liked that it was sleek and efficient.

However, today I plugged it in like usual and nothing! I heard a whizzing sound but the blades wouldn’t budge. Sadly, I tried it in every outlet and nothing. I gave it to my boyfriend to try to dissemble and put it back together but no luck again. Complete waste of money. My cuisinart one from my mom still works though! I definitely would not recommend this one...

reviews.reviewTitle: The new maker is not bad at all but the coffee tasted different because of ...
reviews.reviewText:
We took up the trouble of grinding beans again when we replaced our broken coffee maker. The new maker is not bad at all but the coffee tasted different because of the different size and shape of filter, a bit bitter and doesn't change when adjusting the amount of coffee powder. We still had the old grinder from across the pond but we threw away the transformer, thinking that we will never need it again.

The other grinders at this price level that have adjustable grind buttons are probably gimmicks. With these mechanisms I don't believe you can do an medium grind uniformly. And the different is in seconds. Your eye and hand coordination, try and error, probably works just as well as the adjustable buttons.

The oval shape work just the same as rounded, completing a fine grind in no time (<10 sec?), with most of the fine powder stays on the grinder even when you pour. If you do other things or grind very small amount, that may be different. The minimum I grinded is two to three table spoon of coffee bean that doesn't give me any surprises.

The oval slanted shape makes it easier to pour, and scrape remaining powder into the coffee maker.

The size is a lot bigger than my old one. This one isn't too big for a single person. The bigger size generates less mess when you open it. And I'm sure it will be big enough for a 12 cup coffee maker when you need that. The cover is all clear plastic (acrylic?) so you can wash it after every use if you choose to.

This one comes with no brush. Do you need one? Sure you can make use of it but you have to deal with cleaning it then. I just use a spoon to scrape lightly most of the powder out so the amount of powder doesn't vary a lot for each use. And hopefully, the powder that remains don't accumulate in the corners so they are gradually replaced with fresher powder. Roasted coffee beans have natural oil so it's not easy for them to grow germs. In parts of the world as a custom they don't put an oily roast chicken into the fridge. Of course you can clean the grinder thoroughly once every week or month. I discovered my old grinder still have powder on it since last use a few years ago. It is just like yesterday with no smell or rot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great, but plastic piece on the lid may be a potential issue in the future
reviews.reviewText:
I have some other KRUPS coffee grinders that are older than the hills but still work fine. Unlike the old ones, this new grinder has a little black plastic piece sticking out of the lid which is necessary to trigger the motor. It looks like something that could easily break off. The old grinders had a smooth lid with no pieces that could possibly break off. Also, the cord does not stow away in the body of the appliance like in my old Hamilton Beach grinder (the one that just broke because it had a little plastic piece sticking out that broke off). So storage is awkward.

On the plus side, it has a large capacity and a powerful motor. The oval-shaped body helps the coffee beans to be ground evenly and quickly. I use this machine for coffee only. However, with my old KRUPS grinder, I frequently grind all kinds of spices and nuts for recipes. It works great for this purpose.

The only comments I have and the reason I didn't give 5 stars is my previous grinder lid fit on the outside of the chamber where the coffee beans are and this lid fits along the inside along with the beans. That with the slight tilt in the design of the body of the grinder seems to be a little messy in that unless you are really careful spills of the ground up coffee can happen especially at 4:30 AM. Overall its good as works well to grind the coffee fast and to a fine grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very difficult to clean, but works great
reviews.reviewText:
Works great. We use it as a spice grinder - more often than not taking granulated sugar substitute and making it confectioner's sugar substitute, but also occasionally for other spices like turning granulated garlic into powdered garlic.

However, the problem with this grinder comes when you want to go from one kind of spice to another: it is a major ordeal to get it cleaned out! No one wants garlic-flavored icing! The inner pieces are not safe to be cleaned with water, so you are stuck with trying to brush the powder out, or using compressed air to blow it out (far more effective, but also more expensive on an ongoing basis). Seems like Krups should be able to make the inside washable, which would make this a much more valuable kitchen tool.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor burnt up after less than 6 uses.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this a little over a year ago, I've literally used it 4 times. I bought it to grind up dried fruits and beef jerky to make pemmican, and the first couple batches it worked awesome. Ground up the ingredients real fine in a matter of seconds. I pulled it out of storage (after making sure it was put away clean), went to run some jerky through it, and it died a horrible, mechanical death. Smoke came out of it and while the motor still turns the blades, even the lightest piece of anything makes it stop spinning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product but failed after 2 months with no warranty replacement
reviews.reviewText: The design of this product is nice and for a while it worked great my only complaint at first is that it was very challenging to clean. But then after about 2 months it completely stopped working! This does not seem to be the norm from other product reviews so I contacted KRUPS about a warranty replacement. The customer service rep tersely told me just too look at their website (which obviously I had already checked) and hung up on me. The warranty requires that I drive 6 hours to the nearest service shop, a shop not even owned by KRUPS to not even be gauranteed for them to fix it! All for a $20 product! They definentatly need to figure out a better warranty replacement method. I will not be buying another KRUPS brand product again.

Received the unit and while lifting the box, I wondered why the item rattled. As I proceeded to open the item and remove the contents, ball bearing fell out from the bottom of the unit. I looked at the bottom of the unit and some of the screws were missing. I proceeded to contact Amazon and they were awesome with sending a replacement. I understand things happen but there is no way this should have ever made it past quality control at Krups manufacturing! Also, whoever boxed this up at Amazon should have enough common sense coffee makers are not supposed to rattle! What a pain in the rear. The manufacturing in the US is far inferior than what we use to manufacture back in the day!

reviews.reviewTitle: Failed after only a few uses
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to replace one that started just buzzing (no rotation) instead of grinding, after not a very long life. While this one did a great job grinding when it worked, unfortunately this one did the exact same thing as my previous one. I had it for a year and a half but probably only used it 15-20 times in that period, only for grinding spices. When it did not rotate I tried rotating the blade a little with pliers to see if it was just "stuck" but no luck, still just buzzed with no rotation. The previous one I had disassembled to see if I could lubricate it or otherwise get it to work, but no luck there either. Unfortunately in my experience these are not durable enough, and I will order a different brand in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for Coffee, Maybe Not The Best For Spices
reviews.reviewText:
I bought a few of these in years past. Separate ones for spices, coffee. For coffee I don't have anything but high marks for this grinder. Load it up and go, easy as that. I roast my own coffee, I'm particular about the outcomes of brewing. I can't honestly taste the difference between coffee brewed with grinds from this grinder and that of the burr grinder costing 100.00 more. The grinder itself seems to last forever as long as I only grind coffee with it.
Spices, a different story. It works, but if you overload it just once, its fried. It's not as if it overheats and stops, cools down, try again. Nope, its just toast. You have to toss it.

If you like grinding things into an almost powder in small amounts, this will do it.
I had to purchase this because I don't read carefully and ordered full coffee beans, that I did not have a grinder for - until now.

It works well, for my cold brew system I have to grind probably 4 times to fill it, since this does a little at a time.
It is fairly easy to clean and VERY easy to turn on. If it's plugged in and you put the lid on anywhere near all the way, there it goes!
Seemingly you cannot turn it on without the lid, which is good. Cleaning the blades is like anything else - they are sharp and covered in ground coffee - use a tough sponge.

It's not quiet but I didn't think it would be. It makes a lot less noise than my blender at least.

This is a great low maintenance machine. Great tasting coffee is waiting for me every morning. The auto programing is the best. Makes my work days a little better. If it turned into a beer brewer on the weekends it would be the perfect machine!

I have joined the Coffee Bean Grinder generation! No more buying ground coffee for me. I had NO IDEA that you loose some of the caffeine quality with Ground Coffee. I am WAY more alert these days now that I am grinding my own beans. This little grinder does a fantastic, fast job. Simple, no bells or whistles. Just gets the job done. And at this price, you could afford to have one just for beans, and one just for spices, or nuts, or what have you. LOVE IT!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't leave plugged in if you have kids.
reviews.reviewText:
I have only used this with Star***ks coffee beans. However, it has worked great to grind the beans very finely, and the coffee has always tasted great.
I will say cleaning this thing is not easy. It always leaves a layer of grinds where the lid meets the bowl. I have to turn the whole thing upside down and tap the lid on the palm of my hand to get all the grinds out of the bowl. Otherwise they stick to the bowl.
There are no safety features on this thing. If they wanted to prevent someone from turning on the grinder with the lid off. They would have recessed the button, not put it flush with the top of the grinder. Plus the grinder doesn't know when the lid is removed. So it's really easy for a kid to activate it with the lid off. Don't leave it plugged in if you have kids.

I have been using this coffee grinder for over two years (almost daily) now and it still works just as well as it did new. It is compact and simple. Works perfectly to finely grind beans for use with a paper filter. A permanent filter will not hold the dust and fine particles created by this grinder.

The blades are sharp and very low in the grinder, allowing this unit to pick up and pulverize any stray beans. It does the job in well under a minute. I have found that shaking the grinder for a few seconds followed by grinding for another 5-10 seconds takes care of any stray beans.

The drawback to this unit is the fact that it only has one setting - fine. You can pulse the grinder, but you'll have to experiment to become proficient if you want coarse grounds. The grinder doesn't come with a brush either. This is the first grinder I've owned but my wife said ones she has owned have come with a brush. I just use a plastic spoon to help scrape out the grounds. Works fine for me.

If you need additional options, spend the money on an expensive unit. For the price, this one is a great buy.

Overall, this unit seems near unbreakable and it should last for years to come.

Update: Bought a second grinder, not because the first one stopped working, but because my wife and I both travel for work. Needed a second one when working away from home for extended periods of time.

reviews.reviewTitle: New version of the ones we’ve used for years
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had the old, round grinders for years and years. We had four of them at one time but we’ve killed off two of them over the years due to VERY heavy use, and we’re down to two of them. We don’t use them for coffee, but for herbs and spices. I like to keep one separate for grinding herbal roots, but Father of Mayhem accidentally used it with garlic and now it’s too stinky to use for my dandelion root tea. I ordered this one and I’m so happy! It’s just as good as the original, but somehow seems a little easier to clean...? Maybe that’s because it’s new. I’m throwing another one on the wish list for myself and adding it to the gift list we keep for others.

It grinds your coffee down to molecules if you want it to: this little machine is so efficient! We grind to espresso consistency and it takes about 10-12 seconds. Yes, there's some grinds left clinging to the stainless steel, but just scrape it out, it's not a lot.
Perfect for every morning coffee grinding. Not too noisy, either, for a grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: A good grinder albeit not quite as good as the five stars I would give it's 25 year old twin which is still ticking along.
reviews.reviewText:
I ordered this grinder due to my other Krups still kicking (which is 25 years old and looks identical), fantastic longevity and performance. This one still grinds coffee very well, something the Cusiniart I ordered a couple of years ago due to it's larger appearing capacity does not do.

The newer model has a shorter cord than the original, something I do not like, also, the motor in it is much louder. In fact it is so loud and high pitched it would probably require ear protection use if OSHA found this grinder in the workplace. I noticed that there was a slight modification to the blade design but no real difference in the way it grinds, as near as I can tell. It will pulverize the coffee if you are not careful so you need to watch it.

Now we shall see how long it lasts.

I purchased this grinder because it was touted as a best seller by Amazon. What a disappointment. The load capacity is woefully inadequate. If you need to make 6 or more cups of coffee, be prepared to load this machine twice. Also the plastic top is flimsy and you have to fight to get it snapped together every time. It always makes a mess with grind spillage because you have to load it to the brim unless you want to grind multiple times for one pot of coffee. The cord is short so that you have to unplug it from the outlet to get it to reach the coffee machine unless you want to bring the coffee machine to the grinder. A complete waste of my money as I have to buy another one to replace this ineptly constructed grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Less beans means a more accurate grind
reviews.reviewText: Now, as a barista I like to think I know a little bit about coffee grinding. I was a little skeptical about this but one of my coworkers recommended it, saying that it can actually be pretty accurate... if you know what you’re doing. She recommended to work in small batches (three tablespoons or less) and not only pulse, but shake after each one. I decided to give it a whirl (pun very intended) and found that it actually works better than I originally thought! I used to use a hand grinder which is nice, but kinda annoying when you constantly go from French press to pour over. Now it’s just a matter of how much pulsing. I’m definitely happy I got this product and so grateful of my new freedom of grind size

This is a basic coffee grinder. Firstly, you are not going to get a very fine ground coffee. But it does work exceptionally well and you can get a good fine texture from it. It is rather loud when running. You can only do a small amount at a time. So if wanted to grind an entire pound at one time it would take a while. The does not come out easily and I have to take a teaspoon and scrape around the inside to get it all out. It would be nice if it had came with a brush or something that would make it easier to get the coffee out. All that said, for the price, this works exceptionally well and I would highly recommend it for those who love the taste of freshly ground coffee in the morning.

I don't like this. First of all, it came with NO instructions, I had to hunt them down online, the coffee maker is not easy to figure out, at all. I had a Kitchen Aid coffee maker for years then came to this one and I hate it. It only stays on for 2 hours, the grinder doesn't grind well, there's always chunks. The pot leaks no matter how much is in there.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as nice as I expected when ordering, but it works.
reviews.reviewText:
Like many of the other reviewers have said it does not grind coffee beans equally. I'll have some very well ground coffee and some chunks. I'll generally grind up the chunks finer and have no issues with chunks in my coffee.

I find it very annoying to clean the tank out after each use as it clumps to the bottom of the canister. I only make 1 cup of coffee per day and would rather have fresh ground coffee than grinding for multiple days worth so the cleaning aspect is not something I like.

The power cable is very short which makes it difficult to use the device when near the coffee maker. It is inconvenient to have to use an extension able for a coffee grinder but I've had to do so.

I heard the life of the device isn't that long so I am pretty sure I'll be ordering a better device here shortly. It wasn't a bad $20 purchase but I would not recommend this device nor will I purchase another one.

I purchased this to grind spices, nuts, and chia seeds and it works like a dream. Grinding the chia seeds to make a flour did not take any time at all. It is easy to pulsate it to grind to the consistency you are looking for. Holding the lever down steady will result in a fine powder very quickly. I have ground granular erythritol sweetener to make a fine powder. It works great with grinding granular sugar too. Cleaning it is not difficult. Gentle scraping and using a damp paper towel works for me but be careful as the blades are sharp. I would recommend this grinder to my friends and family.

reviews.reviewTitle: A nice, compact little grinder with a great price
reviews.reviewText: A nice, compact little grinder with a great price.
