This fits nicely on my counter next to my coffee machine without taking up much space and it is a strong, efficient grinder despite its small size. It is easy to clean and I use a clean small paintbrush to dust out grounds residue. I took away one start only because since it is so small, I have to grind coffee in batches to make cold brew. But otherwise, I love it! A good buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Efficient grind, tough getting grounds to the filter
reviews.reviewText:
Grinding is amazingly easy. Getting the coffee grounds to your coffee maker is... well... A grind.
Dumping the beans into the main compartment and pushing down on the exterior button is simple and efficient. No power controls or anything, but I don't mind.
The bigger issue is how to transfer the grounds from grinder to coffee maker. The compartment that grinds the coffee is insight into the main unit, which is plugged in. I find it very difficult scooping out the grinds from the bladed, attached grinder to the filter I'm using. You're limited to a small area and grinds often get stuck under the blades.
A little trick I use is, after grinding, I tip the whole thing upside down so the grounds fall into the clear plastic cover, then use that as a little dispensing bowl for my filter. This is all well and good, if I've ground the exact right amount. If I didn't, I have extra grounds either sitting in the grinder or the plastic lid. Not easy to store, say to in a fridge , to keep the h grounds fresh.
Contrast this to my old Mr Coffee grinder, which had a detachable head that kept the grounds contained and covered, from which I could spoon out into the filter wherever I liked, then store my extras. It worked nicely and it's a shame Krups doesnt have the same. Oh well. Oh also, heads up: n no measurement lines anywhere on the device. At least it does grind like a champ :)

Nice product to replace my Mr coffee grinder from the 80s lol

This product works excellent & the interior chamber is very nice, stays clean. Same with lid.

The only thing I don't like is the semi uneven design where the lid meets the grinder base, I would have preferred an even design
When you turn it over to take the lid off with ground coffee it slides more of the grounds to one side so you have to be careful not to lean it in that direction too much or it spills.

Overall good product that feels it will last a long time. Solid

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee Grinder Still Working Well After Two Years
reviews.reviewText:
Have been using this grinder (for coffee only) for more than 2 years. I use an AeroPress to brew the coffee. Over more than 2 years the grinder has worked well with no drop-off in performance.
I pulse to a grind at the line between fine and coarse, with some shaking and tapping between to make sure the grind is consistent throughout.
With this as grinder and the Aeropress as brewing device, I make very good coffee.
For cleaning I use a moist paper towel, and the grinder still looks pretty clean.

Lots of heavy coffee drinkers at our house and, though we're not coffee gourmets, we like some nicer organic blends and as fresh as possible. I really wanted to try for a nice ceramic burr grinder this time around and that was turning into a major research project. I don't want to pay a fortune for plastic gears and direct contact with burrs that may be full of heavy metals - never mind the non-descript metal burrs, does anyone test what the ceramics are made with? Well, these little blade styles keep those issues a little simpler. Stainless steel blade and cup, minimal contact to the cover. So while the search continues for an electric burr grinder, meanwhile, I just want some decent coffee. Now! For every day drip style, this inexpensive little grinder is fine for our purposes. Alternating pulses with a few gentle shakes during pauses, rather than steady on, keeps both the beans and machine from heating up. Even with that approach, other similar styles used before didn't seem to grind as evenly as this one. The smooth contours of the cup and cap make a bit of clean up after each use very quick and easy. We'll see how long it lasts while, at this price, I could buy and wear out a wholesale lot before I paid for one of the electric burr styles!

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after 45 days!!! What is the warranty?
reviews.reviewText: Hello - I purchased this item on August 1, 2018. I went to grind my coffee for tomorrow morning, and the machine started smoking and now does not work. What is the warranty on this? I am very surprised as this item is not very old and it is meant to grind coffee....very disappointed!!! I know it was $18...but painful as I will now go to Giant Eagle and buy ground coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... my Hiro manual hand crank grinder blades are getting dull and doesn't grind well anymore
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this coffee grinder because my Hiro manual hand crank grinder blades are getting dull and doesn't grind well anymore. I wanted something that will last a lifetime and this will probably last decades because the blades will not get dull.

When you press down on the black button, it will blend the coffee up. The longer you blend it, the more fine the coffee particles become. So if you want to make espressos, you'll hold the button longer. I thought the blades would be razor sharp but it's not, they're flat edge. You don't have to sharpen it in the far future. You also will not cut yourself if you touch it.

Safety feature: The only way the coffee grinder turns on is if the black button is pressed down. If you remove the clear plastic cap with the black button, you can't accidentally turn it on. Not unless you have something narrow and flat like a flat-head screwdriver that will act like the black button.

I have a Watt Meter and initially when you power it up it will spike up to around 160 Watts and then when it's almost finish it will stay at around 115 to 120 Watts. The more coffee you add into it, the more power it will need to grind it up.

When the unit(with the AC power cord) is placed on a digital scale, it will say 1 LB and 6.4 Ounces.

I hope you find this review useful.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after being used about 100 times
reviews.reviewText: We bought this as a back-up grinder for an older Krups we thought was going to break. That one is still going strong (albeit making weird noises) while this newer one lasted no more than about 100 grinds of spices mostly until the blades detached from the axle. Complete waste of money and an insult to the environment. Built-in obsolescence taken much too far.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love this grinder for spices
reviews.reviewText:
FIRST I need to tell you I am new to grinding spices. I have wanted to begin with cloves. I tried using one of those small food processors. HA HA what a joke! Just chopped it up a bit if you can imagine. I also tried placing these whole cloves in a plastic bag and smashing them with a hammer. Another joke! This made many small holes in my plastic bag and the cloves seemed to be indestructible! So I decided to see about using some electric gadget of some sort. Somewhere I came across the idea to use a coffee grinder. So I came here to good ole' Amazon and found me one. Good reviews and looks like this one will last me for many years to come.

I just got this grinder today. I used it on the cloves. (the ones I had kind of chopped up?) It ground the cloves to powder, which is what I wanted. The oils from the cloves did cause the plastic top to become cloudy but I was able to wash that part. The other part you cannot put in water it seems. BUT...as I read some of the posts on here concerning this grinder...one WONDERFUL person posted about how she used uncooked white rice and ground it up to clean the grinder. BINGO! She also stated that she did this twice after grinding cloves. So my problems are solved!

I am so glad I will be able to clean this grinder because I was hoping to also grind flax seeds as well and who knows where this will all lead to?

Bottom line: GLAD I bought this grinder. SHARP blades and works QUICK! ABLE to clean....

This can make a great cup of coffee. It looks good and elegant in the kitchen. I just had a problem with it 2 months ago where the Burr grinder stopped working all of a sudden and out of nowhere and for no good reason what so ever,I made a great coffee on Monday morning but I couldn't make my coffee on Tuesday morning because of the grinder just like that. I unplugged it and left it for 1 hour and plugged it back it didn't work, I ran all the routine cleaning maintenance but it didn't work. I was upset so I hit on the top of the grinder rather strongly with my hand and the grinder started to work just fine and it's been working ever since then with no problem. Lol. I Love it. True story.

reviews.reviewTitle: So good, had to buy another
reviews.reviewText: My wife had this product before I even met her, and used it all the time. When the motor finally burned out the other day. I had no problem at all buying another identical product. It's well made and holds up well. There are bigger grinders that may suit some people better, but for us, this one is a reliable workhorse.

Did not really live up to expectations. Was super excited to receive the product. In the end I feel like water runs too quickly through the included filter resulting in very weak coffee. I've tried several beans now, have the grind size set to the finest setting and strength setting set to strong with no luck. I've even tried grinding extra beans for the amount of water without success.

Update(1/8/2019)
I'm returning this product. This thing is either broken or just brews bad coffee. It was also received with evidence of prior use -- tiny coffee grounds in the shoot leading from the grinder to the strainer.

I really recommend this product. I purchased with the intention of grinding spices and my boyfriend also uses it to grind his coffee. There is no setting for the courseness, you just have to pulse it for a shorter amount of time. It isn't a problem though. I was able to grind my spices very finely and he grinds his coffee course for a French press. Like other reviewers said, I pulse a peace of bread to pick up all the leftover and then wipe it out and it stays in perfect condition.

Broke with first use. This is the same model I used for many years. I expected to recieve many years from the new one I purchased but the very first time I used it to grind a moderate amount of coffee, it smoked and the motor died. The new krups grinder had a 20 second lifespan.

reviews.reviewTitle: I just don’t think its possible to get even, good extraction from your coffee if your beans are not ground evenly.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased the blade grinder...and I wanted a cheap altnernative/decent grinder to get myself started in the coffee industry. I regret purchasing this product for multiple reasons :-(
1. THE GRIND SIZE IS NOT EVEN...You adjust the grind size depending on how long you hold the button down and allow the blades to grind???? Like there are ULTRAAAA fine particles and there are HUGE coarss grounds, this disparity will affect extraction and make it suuuper even even and not tasty.
2. You can’t really control the grind size??? I think the concept of correlating the time the grind button is held to the grind size...is purely for convenience. It’s not as great as it seems like it’s to be.
I just don’t think its possible to get even, good extraction from your coffee if your beans are not ground evenly.

Had a Krups grinder for at least 25 years so when it quit working we ordered this Krups F203 in February, arrived in March and today (April 17) it seized up. We are an elderly retired couple who have used this new Krups grinder for its intended purpose, primarily grinding small quantities of spices, once or twice a week (since March) and cleaning it with a dry cloth (never water). In looking at other customer reviews, which I wish I had done before buying it, I see an awful lot of recent 1 star ratings and agree with the comments (no stars was not available). I want to exchange it for another brand.
Very happy with this purchase, powerful grinder. I used it for grinding coriander seeds.

reviews.reviewTitle: worked great until the lid cracked & chipped
reviews.reviewText: I've had mine for a little over 3 years and have generally been quite happy with it. (I use it exclusively for grinding herbs, spices, and seeds, not coffee. I probably use it once a month or so.) However, the plastic lid developed a crack at some point that recently became a chip, which rendered the grinder useless, because now each time I use it, more little plastic bits break off. I found a site where I can get a replacement lid for $4 but when you add in shipping, it's already halfway to the cost of a totally new grinder, and I worry that I'll get a new lid only to have the motor burn out. (If you happen to want one of these for grinding herbs, please be warned NOT to ever try grinding dried hawthorn berries. That's what really did mine in.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Simple, inexpensive, easy to clean, well made
reviews.reviewText: This is the best spice and coffee grinder out there. The design is simple, it is effective, cheap, and they last forever. I used one every day for about ten years until I finally dropped it and cracked plastic top. I replaced it with two more, one for coffee and one for spices, and both are still as well made as the original. There are others out there with additional bells, whistles and bows. I've tried several and always been disappointed. Some have floppy tops. Some have added features that make them harder to clean. Grinding coffee isn't rocket science. After a few uses, you'll be able to hear when it's ground fine enough. One button operation. The shape of the top makes it easy to pour the grounds into the filter basket or a measuring cup when you're done.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stay away, don’t waste your money!
reviews.reviewText: This was a gift for my mother and it left everyone in the family beyond disappointed. You can’t imagine how frustrated a person can be when they can’t get their morning cup of coffee without constantly trying to make the machine work. This machine won’t grind your coffee, whatever you do! It worked alright for the first couple of weeks, and that was it. We’ve had it for almost a year now, which I regret immensely. At some point it started working just fine so we thought, alright, let’s not return it, maybe it was just a temporary issue and it won’t happen again. But it did. It did and now I have an entire bag of coffee beans I’ve got nothing to do with, and a machine that won’t do it’s job. And that’s for over $100 bucks! Total waste of money and it makes me angry that now I can’t return it as I waited too long. Stay away from this trash. It will make your morning routine absolutely miserable.

I buy true cinnamon (Ceylon cinnamon) in its form of softer, almost papery curled sticks (compared to the hard, thick version), and grind my own for freshness. (For those using cinnamon for its health benefits, the stuff you get in grocery stores is NOT effective in that regard. It's actually Cassia, and will flavor food, but that's all.) I also order green cardamom from India, to make the wonderful Chai type of tea, and sometimes I grind it to flavor hot chocolate. This grinder does the job beautifully, giving me close to a powder even with fairly hard substances.

reviews.reviewTitle: Krups Electric Grinder: Small and Powerful
reviews.reviewText:
I use the Krups Electric Grinder every morning to grind coffee beans. I want a very fine grind for pour-overs. The Krups Electric Grinder achieves a very fine ground beans for pour-over, in under one minute! If I want a coarse grind for french press, it takes about 20 seconds or less to grind. It feels very durable. I use the lid to measure the coffee beans too.
There is some grinding noise during operation, but not terribly noisy. It uses such a short time to go from fresh whole beans to coffee grind that the noise is not a problem. Highly Recommend !!

Wow! Fast, fast, fast.

First, I DO NOT use this for coffee - I use it exclusively for nuts. I have to be very careful because it is so quick, two or three pulses is enough. I imagine, given what it does to nuts, it must pulverize coffee. I replaced my old Toastmaster brand with this one. That brand was more controlled for my purpose. I could get a good chop without pulverizing the nuts. With the Krups, I need to be quick.

Although I have not used this for coffee, I can tell by how it handles walnuts, almonds, etc., that you can get a course ground down to espresso ground very easily and QUICKLY with this brand.

Thanks

This is the first coffee grinder I have ever purchased, so I do not have a baseline for comparing the Krups grinder. But I have owned Krups appliances in the past and have been impressed with the quality of of them. This coffee grinder has lived up to that standard. The blades are very sharp and are able too grind a batch of coffee beans in a few seconds. I don't particularly like the high-pitched whine of the motor. It reminds me of the coffee grinder a housemate used back in 1980, The piercing sound in the morning used to drive me crazy. But I suppose that this is the way it is with coffee grinders, no getting around it. It does a fine job of what it is supposed to do, and that is the main thing.

This works as expected. I was trying to grind some fennel seeds to make my own 5 spice powder. This grinder works fine and cleans out with a brush, as others suggested. Don't need to toss it in the dishwasher and ruin it. The noise level did not register with me, very likely it is the same as a blender. Blenders will not grind up fennel seeds and make the same amount of noise. Fresh ground spices have significant aroma over pre-ground spices. Taste is good too.

Does not give a consistent grind - half is powder and the other half are large flakes. This model says it can also do nuts, well if you want nut dust maybe. Again, the bottom was powder and the top were big pieces. Also the design is incredibly messy, the grinds stick to the top of the lid and fly everywhere when you open it. Regretful purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good spice grinder... wish it had ability to control coarseness
reviews.reviewText: Bought this to grind/mix spices for prime rib. I'm surprised that a blade based grinder can grind spices into a fine powder in seconds. This was a mistake for me and I had to re-do my grind and limit it to 4s or less for the coarsness I needed. The quality is good. Came in Amazon frustration free packaging. I can't comment on this for coffee. For this, I prefer a burr based grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: As long as it doesn't jam this is a great product.
reviews.reviewText: Got it for Coffee grinding usage. Works really well while it works which unfortunately is very short lived. The Grinder got jammed (even though I wash it after every use) after I used it a few times and stored it. They sent a replacement unit and the same thing happened to the replacement unit. I would say if you going to use it for coffee grinding then get a burr grinder rather than these chomping blades. As long as it doesn't jam this is a great product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder for spices, but not coffee
reviews.reviewText:
Pros: Cheap, powerful motor and blades
Cons: Uneven grind, smallish capacity

If you're looking for a coffee grinder, I wouldn't recommend a bladed one, especially if you care about using the right size grind for the right drink. Blade grinders are cheap, but a burr grinder ensures a uniform grind, which is important to get a consistent flavor and brew. This grinder, however, would be perfect for spices, and I would actually recommend using it only for that. Cleaning is relatively easy: just use a damp paper towel to wipe up the remains and a dry one to finish the job.

LOVE THIS!! This grinder turns my coffee beans into a fine powder in seconds. It is really easy to use just put in your coffee or spices, put on the lid and push the button. The blade spins continuously as you hold the button down. It doesn't run loud and it's not quiet either (medium noise) but not annoying at all. When I'm done grinding the coffee I just wipe it out and put it back in the cabinet. Fresh coffee in seconds!! If this review was at all helpful, please let me know by clicking on helpful. Thank you so much!! :)

When I purchased this coffee grinder I did it without reading the reviews (I always do, religiously)
When I went back and read all the bad reviews I kicked myself in the ass for not having checked out what all the people had to say about it and how bad it is and how it broke down on them.
I want to ask something to those people....what the f&%& were you trying to grind, nails? Chairs or what? Please people!
I make my own chinese 5 spices and grind up coffee every day. I was so worried that after the first few days it hadn't broken that I even put parmesan cheese in the damn thing and it ground it down to a fine dust.
Go ahead and buy this grinder, It's really cool.

I bought this to replace an old brew & grind (that stopped grinding) by Cuisinart, and now I really miss that coffee maker! First, it makes great coffee. I love that I can adjust grind size and strength. Stays hot. Auto-brewing is fabulous. BUT, I have to clean the grinding compartment much more often than I think one should. In truth, it isn't the cleaning that is such a big deal, but it is the hatch that covers where you clean that is tricky and difficult to remove. It's just as challenging to put it back in place. It's just an added step that makes this pot a bit more inconvenient than I thought it would be.

reviews.reviewTitle: MESSY! Good Coffee--But for price range of abt. $140 another brand might well without this mess!!
reviews.reviewText: As usual, before purchasing a product, I read many of the numerous reviews. I found nothing that seemed a significant concern. Received it this Dec. 2018 with Amazon's characteristic timeliness and sturdy packaging. BUT after making coffee for the first time this week on several days, discovered what seems a unavoidable and time-consuming clean up mess from coffee grounds inside that then scatter everywhere (counter, etc.) during clean up. SO I went back to descriptions to re-read. Eventually found many that referenced "messy" when using that in word in my search. However, these comments were not easily found otherwise. I noticed that mixed with questions and reviews on all topics were numerous comments focused ONLY on the coffee bean grinder, as if it were the only component! Why would anyone pay this for a coffee maker and ONLY ask or discuss what kinds of spices you can grind? A few did refer to spices that impact the coffee flavor, but many did not. I began wondering if the site might be including other KRUPS products such as their separate grinders under one big category! Whether this is true or not, the significant focus on the grinder for so many comments seems to result in more than typical difficulty in discovering negative comments about the coffee itself, especially the unavoidable "messy" characteristic, unrelated to the grinder! (Grinding beans or using coffee already ground produced similar results!) Two stars for very good coffee could easily have been four or five stars if the product was constructed to provide even the clean up ease of a very basic "Mr. Coffee" maker! I am an avid Amazon consumer. It is uncharacteristic for me to ever write a negative review. However, I would not purchase THIS product again unless the "messy" characteristic was effectively resolved!

reviews.reviewTitle: Krups - Not What it Use to Be
reviews.reviewText: The brand is not what it use to be. I used this 3 times before it stopped working. The motor appears to be working but the grinder is not, It would not be so bad to go without coffee for a few days but the customer service is terrible. They take you through a maze to ensure that you give up before you get help. First you are lucky if you find the link to contact them on their website (it is not very clear in any of the warranty or instructions shipped with the product). Next, you get an e-mail requesting the same information you sent them but more. I am going to have to go buy another coffee grinder...any reliable brand recommendations?

reviews.reviewTitle: the most terrible coffee machine I have ever owned
reviews.reviewText: In not so many words this coffee machine is by far the worst I have ever owned. We made coffee... used good quality beans and all we got was a light brown drip... Tried all the grind options, just in case and we only used the Strong Option for the aroma. Needles to say that we are returning it today. Also, like it wasn't disappointing enough to be unable to make a decent cup of joe, we need to return it at a Kohl's store... not at a UPS location which was the most convenient way.

reviews.reviewTitle: 1st one broke, Krupp’s replaced it with a 2nd
reviews.reviewText:
Bought one of these about 5 years ago...I was so sad when it started to die, immediately wanted to purchase the same make, from a trusted brand!

I had my “new” grinder for about a month before the motor went out. Contacted amazon who connected me with Krupp’s, because of their one year warranty, I was sent a replacement for free, and while waiting for it to show was a bummer, I was pleased with the interaction and found it totally worth it for the product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works, but there are better grinder out there.
reviews.reviewText: To be honest, this unit grinds coffee just fine, my issue is the mess and amount of coffee it will hold and a couple other issues. Everytime I take the clear top off, coffee dust flys all over the place and coats my counter. Also, with finely ground coffee, it tends to "cake" together and I end up having to scrape it out with my finger everytime to get it all out. I like stong coffee and the coffee capacity of this unit is just too small for a 12 cup coffee maker. I wore out a Mr. Coffee grinder and went with this one due to the reviews being higher. I am ordering another Mr coffee grinder due to the capacity being larger, you remove the entire cup after grinding, give it a twist to loosen any "caked" grounds, and pour it into your filter. It's larger, cleaner and empties all of the grounds out. Plus it has settings for how many cups you want to grind (it shuts off after a set amout of time) and has 3 grind settings.

Bought this in July 2016 and used it maybe 25 times as instructed. Today the entire screen mechanism and plunger fell apart. Very disappointed with this chintzy press.
SIXTO

I'm not a coffee drinker so no idea how this works for coffee beans BUT.... I've used it for other purposes in the kitchen. First was to chop pecans, it made quick work of them and was much much easier than my hand chopper.

I've also used it to grind black peppercorns. Wow, just a few seconds and fresh ground pepper.

Finally, I used it with granulated monkfruit to make a fine confectioner's-sugar-type powder. Again, just a few seconds and it was done!

I'm really going to like having this in the kitchen. Pretty sure it will handle your coffee beans with no problems.

reviews.reviewTitle: So great that my mom got jealous and bought her own
reviews.reviewText:
I've had one for a couple years now and it's never failed me. I recently moved out of the house and I think my mom was going to miss that coffee grinder more than her own daughter. At least this second one could fill the empty hole in her heart.

It certainly does the job and grinds up whole beans in just a few seconds. I'm not sure of the "proper" way to use it but I've found that giving the grinder a little vertical shake while holding the button gives a more even consistency to the grounds, otherwise the beans closest to the blades will turn into a finer grind than whats on the top.

This machine has a serious design flaw — some of the grinds don’t make it all the way into the basket for brewing. They get caught in the chute between the grinder and the basket. So, they sit there until you make your next pot, at which point they get pushed into the basket and you get stale coffee. It might not be super noticeable if you make a couple of pots a day, but I usually only make coffee at home on the weekends and the first pot tastes awful.

There is no practicable way to clean out that shoot — you can sort of scoop the grinds out and make a mess but you can still only get about half of them.

Do not buy.

Great coffee grinder. Chops up coffee quickly and efficiently, taking just a few seconds from beans to grounds. There are no settings so you have to eyeball your grind, which is not a problem for me. Motor seems quite powerful when revving. Owned for over a year with continuous use and so far works just as good as when I opened it new. I like the small footprint of the device as well.

The only recommendation I would have for this product would be to have a retractable power cord like what you would see on a nice iron. I put mine away after I am done and it is a little tedious to keep wrapping the power cable around the base, but that is just a very minor quibble.

The price and quality combination of this device cannot be beat. Recommended.

This is a small grinder that works great for my morning cup of coffee at the office. Its quiet enough not to distract my coworkers and does a good job grinding the beans down quickly. It only has a pressure activated switch so grind size is controlled by how long it runs. It cleans up with a quick wipe down and leaves no mess behind. I would recommend to anyone trying to use a french press or have fresh ground coffee in the office or on the go.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fast, Simple, and Easy to Store
reviews.reviewText:
I can only compare this product to our cuisinart coffee grinder that we bought at Costco and the professional grinders at the grocery store. And I can tell you HANDS DOWN that this is a significantly superior product to the cuisinart and MUCH easier to use that the grocery store models. Also, the price on this thing is about half of what I paid for the cuisinart grinder at Costco, and it died in less than a year.

This grinder is small and easy to store. While it doesn't hold a ton of beans, it grinds them in a matter of seconds. We never grind more than 1 or 2 loads of beans anyway because you don't want the coffee to loose its freshness by being ground for too long before use.

If you're just looking into grinding your own coffee, this grinder makes it so easy. ALSO, when you grind your own beans, you have a MUCH greater selection of coffee to choose from (there are more types available in bulk and whole-bean form than in ground form).

I strongly recommend this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: I do not use it for coffee beans
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this for grinding seeds (pumpkin, sunflower, sesame, and flax). I haven't used it for spices. Every time I grind seeds, they get stuck in a layer under the blade. I have to use my finger to scoop the stuff out. That situation probably doesn't happen with spices and coffee, but I don't know. It's not that big of a deal to me, but it gets messy and I spill the ground up stuff every time. The 4/5 stars actually comes down to the fact that this coffee grinder doesn't come apart for easy cleaning (unlike my Hamilton Beach grinder).

This grinder does well otherwise! It's fast too. I am pretty positive that with every other grinder I use for seeds, the ground up seeds will get stuck in a layer under the blade. Ha ha.

When set to brew 2 or 4 cups it always brewed twice as much and produced very weak coffee even on the bold setting. Also used a lot more coffee beans than manual coffee makers. It also employs a basket filter as opposed to the cone filters Krups used to make a point of the fact that cone filters make better coffee. Where did the quality go?

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Product, but not Durable. Broken after 3 uses.
reviews.reviewText:
Hi all,
Please know this product was able to grind our coffee to our liking. We had little complaints when it was working. However, its durability is in question. We only used this grinder 3 times and it is already broken. This was purchased less than 2 months ago and it is not working properly. We have the grinder plugged in and we are following the steps, but there seems to be an electrical issue that broken within the wiring or connect to the blades to spin.

If you are the retailer reading this review, please know we are unhappy with the durability and there should be no reason for this product to be broken after minimal usage. Please let us know where we can properly leave a complaint with your team.
Thank you,
Michael

I use "coffee" grinders to grind my own herbs and spices and have been using a wonderful grinder by another company for many years. I needed a replacement and did a lot of research before settling on the Krups.

I can't tell anyone how it grinds coffee... but spices are ground perfectly. Keep in mind that you must put enough in the cup for best results. If a recipe calls for a pinch of something... well, you might have to grind more than you need, or just use a mortar and pestle for the small quantities.

The grinder stops grinding almost immediately upon release of the button which is great when you have achieved the grind you want. It is relatively quiet for a grinder of this type... but as with *any* coffee/spice grinder... it is not quiet enough to fire up while the family is sleeping in the morning. Ha.

As for the reviews in which the lid/cup is hard to remove... Yes, it is... for the first few times of using it. It has been painstakingly paired with the base and fits very snugly. Once you start getting some particles of coffee or spices in the cup it will become much easier to remove because the "dust" from the coffee etc acts as a type of lubricant... so don't give up on such a great product. I would rather have lids that fit more securely than fall off anyway.

All in all I am very pleased with this grinder and highly recommend it for grinding spices of all kinds.

My husband likes to make French Press coffee on the weekends when he's got time and had heard about having fresh ground beans is the true way to go so I bought him this and he's so happy to have his fresh ground coffee. I've even used it to grind freeze dried strawberries into a dust to make strawberry buttercreme frosting and it was great! It was easy to clean between the different types of food so I didn't have coffee/strawberry frosting. :)

We owned this brand coffee grinder that we have used for 25 years. We were happy to replace it when we saw this brand here on amazon. Unfortunately, this grinder stopped after a single-use. I would have given it 0 if it was given because this item is not returnable!! Amazon is considering to refund as soon as this was dropped off at USPS. This brand is great if you find the authentic one! I am afraid what we got is a knock off

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a LOT faster than I expected.
reviews.reviewText: I was previously using a hand-grinder in some misplaced attempt to "connect" with my coffee. The 10 minutes of cranking for a 12 cup pot of coffee got old pretty quick. Enter the KRUPS F203... I guess the purists would recommend only grinding what you need each day but I wanted to try it out and got carried away and was able to blast through an entire 12 oz. bag of Starbuck's beans in about 3 minutes. For a standard amount for a 12-cup brew I'd estimate you could go from beans to ground coffee in under 5 seconds. Cleanup was easy, I used the suggestion to grind up a handful of rice (idea found in the Q&A section here, thank you!).

I love grinding whole spices because they taste so much better. Whole spices can be kept for years and still taste fresh when newly ground. This one does grind—or I should say pulverizes— very well. It is hard to clean. You can only wipe it out with a damp cloth, as I learned the hard way when I broke my first one running it under the faucet to rinse it out.

Worked great at first, then started shutting off on it's own for no reason in the middle of brewing, and now when you plug it in, it comes on and then shuts off within 15 seconds. Now I have to go through the hassle of finding a repair location to have it fixed for what I am sure will be covered by warranty - Would not buy this item again!
We really wanted to love this grind and brew machine. The first one lasted about a month bwfore the grinder stopped. The replacement lasted a week before the grinder stopped.

I was thrilled when the machine arrived--it looked great and I was excited to have access to fresh-ground coffee. Unfortunately, the product was broken. Specifically, the water pump would not bring water from the basin to be brewed. That's kind of an important part of the whole coffee machine thing. The grinder, on the other hand, purred like a well-honed machine--it would have made great ground coffee that could never have been brewed.

I do not know if my experience is anomalous, but I do know that I resent having to spend tomorrow afternoon going to UPS to return this product. In any case, you have been warned.

reviews.reviewTitle: A simple easy grinder can be improved
reviews.reviewText: The product is very well made, and easy to use, small size for easy storage, I would like to give a five star rating, however, two things bothering me. One is cleaning, the grinding area can not be washed, has to be wiped down after use. I have to use a plastic knife to scrape the grounds off the bottom and sides, you may try to use a stiff brush. The second thing is that you need to time yourself to grind the coffee for coase or fine. The coffee grounds are not totally even either. I used a Mr.Coffee grinder before until the plastic parts inside broke and pieces were mixed into my coffee, that was the main reason I ended up bought this Krup grinder. Now I kind of miss my old grinder which can be taken apart for washing ( the plastic part prevents the grounds sticking to the bottom and wall.) and it has fine, medium and coase setting which it shuts down automatically even you are still holding the button. I hope Mr.Coffee would use thin stainless steel scraper to replace the plastic scraper inside.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great to grind your own coffee.
reviews.reviewText: I never had the time before to try out a coffee grinder. It was an experiment, and I am pleased. I don't use the gourmet coffee beans, at least not yet, but I do find a taste difference between the freshly ground and packaged ground coffees of the same brand. I used to use the coffee grinders in the supermarket, but people don't seem to know how to use them correctly, leaving a lot of their ground coffee left in the machine. Even though I clean it out before I grind, I still can't help feeling that I am getting some additional different coffees. This is great, works easy and well.

reviews.reviewTitle: This works the best!! And very reasonably priced
reviews.reviewText: I have bought several coffee grinders and vitamin grinders for crushing medicine & vitamins for a feeding tube. This works the best!! And very reasonably priced. It can be adjusted to grind to a fine powder, even crushes capsules! I have used it for over 2 months and it is still going strong. A little dust comes up when you lift the lid, but a lot less than others that I have purchased. Self grinders do not have powder fly up, but become very tiring when you have a lot of medicines & vitamins to grind. I will definitely buy this again, when needed (probably will buy again as a back up!)

reviews.reviewTitle: Krups F203 Grinder is just what we needed!
reviews.reviewText: I thought that maybe the holder was small, but nope, it holds a lot. Reviews here talk about how it does not have "grind" selections. I worried about that also, but all you have to do is look at what your grinding to decide when to stop grinding. Not a big deal here, but some people need all the help that they can get. It has a clear top that you can see what is going on in the grinder. Another thing that I like, what ever you are grinding does not leave the bowl. The last Krups grinder that I had, the coffee beans or spices fed down into and out another hole to the collection vessel. After a while it gets caked up and burns up. Not this one. Once you finish grinding, you dump out the product. I like this much better. Kudos!

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor design, poor quality of grind.
reviews.reviewText: Very cheap construction, worst engineering I've ever seen. Grinding bowl is both oval and the rim is horizontally offset. The pockets at the two ends of the oval collect coarse ground particles that never circulate for fine grind, no matter how long it runs. The weirdly offset rim of the bowl in the base(one side is nearly 2cm shorter than the other) makes it impossible to do more than half fill the bowl and consequently not only is the grind always coarse but it takes twice as many fills to achieve the quantity usual. And the power cord is only 40cm long AT BEST! Gimme a break! I miss my Braun!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for lower price starter blender
reviews.reviewText: This works exactly as other reviews say. Just depends on what you are looking for. Kinda loud, like i tried to use it in my office building, got embarrassed at the noise and brought it back home, but now use it happily in my own house. I read other reviews that its difficult to clean. Completely understand that. Because it doesnt have a removable container you kind of have to wash the whole thing out with water. But that doesnt seem to have been a problem for it. Definitely some crevices that are a little more difficult to clean, but all in all really not that bad. I agree it probably doesnt give you the best perfectly ground beans. I like to give it a little shake as i grind it. But with a little shake it does the job. Its pretty cheap and im drinking some random coffee beans so maybe not for the super refined palate but absolutely great for a starter grinder. Been using for about two months now. Real random purchase, not paid review.

I have had this model for over a year and mainly use for grinding seeds (flax and cashews mainly). My daughter ordered this one as she has been using mine for grinding coffee for her expresso. Seems to be the best out there for the money. So far 18 months no problems on mine.

I ABSOLUTELY love this grinder. I have had it a few months now and I have had no problems grinding anything I want. I have used it on fresh herbs and it does grind/blend just fine as long as its in liquid and has enough volume for the blades to reach it (essentially you're blending it). I have used it to put together various salad dressings and it works just as well for that as for grinding coffee. As far as grinding coffee, I'm not sure why some reviews said that it doesn't make coarse grounds, I've been able to make coarse grounds just fine, but you have to make it in small batches, just enough beans to cover the silver part inside, then just blast it four short times and the grounds are perfectly coarse. If you fill it and grind it for a while you'll get very fine grounds. Something I do want to note is the design. As others have mentioned, the slanted design does cause grounds to fall out if you try utilizing the whole lid worth of beans. Either you can limit how far you fill it (to the shorter end) or you can fill it up and after grinding unplug it, tip it upside down and remove the lid with the freshly ground coffee/herbs inside the lid. All in all, awesome product, especially for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Small, easy to use, does it's job well
reviews.reviewText: Love this spice grinder. It works amazingly well to grind up herbs and other materials with ease. I do wish the blade and metal grinding "cup" were removable for easier cleaning, but for the price, who cares! Per reading online, if you do end up grinding something sticky, or that is difficult to remove, throw a piece of bread in there and it will soak up any residue. And old, clean paintbrush is also helpful for cleaning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a great job...until it died just after a year.
reviews.reviewText:
29JAN2018
I have the blade unit, I like how it works on grinding up spices; which is what I got it for. Unfortunately, I had only used it half a dozen times before the motor seized up, and the heaviest thing I ever ground with it was peppercorns. Thankfully, it's got a two-year warranty through Krups; their process is pretty simple, call them and they'll provide an email to send them a picture of the unit with the cord cut. I will update my review when the replacement arrives.

reviews.reviewTitle: Did not come in original box, like it was used.
reviews.reviewText: Ordered as part of a coffee lover gift set but this came in a plain, unmarked cardboard box and didnt even have the original instructions...as if this was a used product. I did not purchase a used product but missed the return deadline. :(

reviews.reviewTitle: Roughly comparable to the Braun KSM2
reviews.reviewText:
I just bought one of these to replace my venerable Braun KSM2, which gave out after 20+ years of use. The F203 was just about the only unit I could find that was comparable in design to the Braun -- so many of the newer units are larger and IMO clunkier to store. I'm a pretty heavy coffee drinker, and I work from a home office full-time, so my coffee grinder is among the most important appliances I own.

So far, I'm happy with the F203 Krups. The motor is spec'd at slightly higher power than the Braun, not that this was ever a problem before.

The F203 has an oval cross-section (viewed from above) which makes the coffee a little easier to pour than the round shape of my old Braun. I wish the coffee well (below where the lid separates) was just slightly deeper, but I'm getting used to it.

My only complaint so far is that the bearings have slightly more vibration than my old unit. It feels sturdy enough, and given the light duty cycle that a home coffee grinder enjoys I suspect it will last many years.

This is the second one of this grinder that I owned in 12 years, is always great quality.
It grinds coffee, nuts, seeds and also spices ( bay leaf, clove, anis etc.
I grind here nuts and seeds for pancakes, like pumpkin, almonds, pistachios etc, also I use it for Clove which is dificult to use as it comes in a whole piece, you can use it for oatmeal too, It grinds the oatmeal very fine so I added on my daughter scramble eggs, is all breakfast in one.
I would of love only one different thing : the blades to be movable so I can clean it better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Retiring the last one after 10+ years...hope this is as good
reviews.reviewText: This is the same Krups model as I've had for many years. I think the old one could be repaired with enough tools, as motor still hums, but think the new one iis less expensive than a bunch of new tiny pliers. The old one seemed to give up on October 8, 2008, the day Lehmann Bros. tanked and I had quit my job. Thought it was an omen. However, after a few weeks that one started up again, and has worked every day since. You can determine how fine you want by the length of time of grinding. Nothing fancy. The blade never wore out. You wash the lid in soap, even dishwasher, and just wipe out the mechanism with cloth. The design is also simple and sleek, not take up much room. So based on my experience with the old one, totally recommend it. But I do know that many appliances are not built to last as much as even 15 years ago.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best little coffee grinder I've ever owned.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a small, simple, hand held grinder. Remove the lid and fill with coffee beans, tip the grinder upside down, place over the lid, turn unit right side up, and grind. When you're done grinding, tip it upside down and remove the lid.
I won one of these (along with a pound of coffee) in a radio contest back in 1984 and just replaced it with a new one. (The old one still works, though, and I use it for dried spices.) I also bought one for my son to have in his new home as he grew up using the old one. So often the new ones are disappointments because typically they don't make things like they used to but this is a product that does not seem to have changed and I truly thank Krups for that.

KRUPS F203 Electric Spice & Coffee Grinder

It's my first grinder and so far I really like it. I didn't give it 5 stars because that means "I love it". However I wish that it came with a little brush that allowed me to wipe the grounds to clean it. I'm not having luck finding a little brush at the stores. I'm not taking off stars because of this as the cleaning brush was not promised to me in any details or descriptions. I wouldn't have minded paying a buck more for it though. Again, this is my first grinder and wasn't prepared for how to clean it. Otherwise the blade doesn't come off so that you can give it a good wipe with a rag.

Great grinder, good price. I just need some help in the ol' cleaning department before I go with "I love it".

I made two pots of coffee in it, both with the whole bean grinder. The third time, it simply would not start the grinding process. I unplugged it and plugged it back in and the display was messed up. The backlight would not come on and it just displayed "544". Pushing the Grind/Brew button just changed it to "555" then "666" then "777" then 5, 6, 7, 8 etc.

It's obviously broken. This thing is junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: Low Cost - Very Good Grind - Not the Easiest to Clean
reviews.reviewText: I bought this grinder for three reasons. 1) It had sufficient capacity to make a full pot of coffee at one time. 2) It provided the ability to vary fineness of grind, 3) It makes grinding herbs and spices as snap, and 4) the price was right. The only issue I have is that the grinding chamber if not really easy to clean. If you're grinding things that are oily or very aromatic, it can be a challenge to get it ready for the next thing you're grinding. Part of the reason is that the grinding chamber and blades are permanently fixed and cannot be removed and the grinder is not dishwasher safe or submersible. The trick to cleaning it is to use a damp paper towel to get all of the grind residue, then a slightly soapy paper towel to de-oil the chamber, especially under the cutting blades and finally rinse it with another dampened paper towel. The whole thing takes about 3-4 minutes to clean, but is a little awkward. Other than the cleaning, I love this grinder and would probably buy it again unless the make one with a removable chamber.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder! Only had it for a few days, but as long as it lasts it's a buy for sure!
reviews.reviewText:
So far so good! Had this a few days now and it has been working great! The taste of fresh ground coffee just cant be met with pre-ground stuff.

The pros: This guy isn't overpowered and is really simple to use, Just one hold down button and the longer you hold the finer the grind. Obviously a bladed grinder isn't going to be as uniform or a grind as a more expensive mill grinders etc. but this little guy does a surprisingly good job. For a french press I go with a coarse grind and with this full that's about 3 presses of 3 seconds each. For a finer espresso grind I go with about 15 total seconds, maybe 20.

The cons: It's a little loud. I realize that's a trade off for cost and size, and although a little loud, I think the balanced it pretty well, I wouldn't want it larger. I live in an apartment and work an alternative schedule, so I worry when I'm up and leaving for work in the middle of the night and make coffee that my neighbors might be bothered.

The only reason this guy got four stars from me is that I have not had it long enough to judge it's durability. If this lasts without problem it will be a 5 star rating. As long as it lasts a decent amount of time, say a few years, I would purchase the same one again.

I absolutely hate this coffee grinder. It has such a poor design, the lip is slanted so I spill coffee grinds everywhere when I open it. It Is suppose to be able to grind enough beans for a 12 cup machine but doesn’t. It’s loud and not easy to use at all. Very messy. It sucks!

reviews.reviewTitle: Very loud and smells like the motor is burning up.
reviews.reviewText: I currently have an older Krups type 203 blade grinder (made in Hong Kong) that has been excellent for me. I purchased this new one to keep at the office. The first disappointment with this new version was the noise. It is much louder and harsher than my old one, which hums very quietly and effortlessly. The second (and perhaps more problematic) disappointment was the smell of burning plastic/metal coming from the housing. The housing was also getting quite warm...something I never experienced with my current model. Needless to say, this is going back and I will not be considering a new Krups grinder anymore. This new model is made in China and the manufacturing is not up to the standards of the old Krups 203 grinders. I now realize I am not alone in my experience as there are many reviews citing similar problems. I have no idea how this grinder is rated as high as it is. Unless you want a loud, angry sounding grinder that smells of overheating motor parts....stay far away from this Chinese made Krups grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Only coffee grinder you'll ever need
reviews.reviewText: I'm a devout coffee addict and this is the only coffee grinder I use. This product lasted me for over a year now and I use it almost daily and never had an issue. I use this for my moka pot and it grinds my beans finely enough for espresso.

I've had this for many months and have used it almost daily since buying. I use it primarily to grind coffee beans in the morning and it works like a charm. The blades are still sharp and I have zero complaints. I used it for oats when my son was a baby to get a nice smooth consistency and it worked awesome for that too. Highly recommended. It's small (about the size of a pint glass) and easily cleaned and stored.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fairly quiet and easy to use
reviews.reviewText:
I am so glad I read many reviews from both versions of this coffee bean grinder by Krups (the burr and the blade). Due to everything I read, I decided to buy the blade grinder, and have no regrets.

The grinder is very simple to use: open the top, pour in the beans, place the top back on, and depress the button until you have the grind you want. I did find that not overfilling the container, and stopping partway through to shake it a tiny bit before continuing were good tactics for getting the grind I want.

For noise levels, I think it's fairly quiet for what it is. You will have noise, of course - it's grinding hard beans! I don't appear to have woken anyone up or irritated anyone watching tv in our open-plan home, however, so for what it does, it's quiet IMO.

The thing most people complained about was difficulty getting it clean. This is also my one complaint, but it isn't a huge one. I tip the grinder over my garbage and give it a few good thwacks, then take a paper towel and wipe everything out well. You do have to try to get into the area under the blade, but with the paper towel protecting my fingers this isn't a big deal. If you have a small brush that may help; I do not.

All in all I'm pleased with my purchase. It's excellent value for the money and I am thrilled I can grind fresh coffee whenever I want, now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great efficient grinder at a great price!
reviews.reviewText:
I almost went with another grinder that was advertised as "quieter" while this one was reviewed as being a usual loud volume. Fortunately, someone also mentioned that the noise this grinder makes is moot because it grinds so quickly, it's only loud for a moment. This is very true. This little grinder can reduce coffee beans to grinds in just a few short seconds. The way it's been designed, it sucks all the heavy whole beans down into its blades and forces the lighter ground beans to the top. This flow makes for a near-instant grind. It's impressive.

It's also very compact and looks nice enough to leave on my counter top between uses. The inside of the grinding compartment is very slick, making cleanings quick and easy. The top lid is a thick transparent plastic. Up-ending the unit after grinding puts all the grounds into the lid for easy transport to the coffee machine, or to a container for storage.

Overall, this was a terrific purchase, especially for the very reasonable cost.

I bought this to replace my old grinder. It's functional, but there are two things that made me give it a three-star review. First, it's loud. Compared to my Gloria Jeans grinder (RIP), it's really loud. And secondly, the lid inset is really long and is difficult to pull out when there is coffee in the device. The solution I've found is to minimize the amount of beans added to prevent spilling grinds when you are forcefully pulling the lid off.

reviews.reviewTitle: Controllable, visible grinding, very good product.
reviews.reviewText: This is the third one of these I’ve bought, and I’ve been happy with each one. Krups has been making this guy for years, and I will keep buying them when they wear out or get borrowed and not returned. Good stuff. Since you can see what’s going on in the bowl, it’s easy to see when to stop grinding. It gives a lot of control. Some people have complained that it gets too warm for grinding coffee, but that hasn’t been an issue with any of the ones I’ve had.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder is the equivalent of using a hammer to ...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is the equivalent of using a hammer to drive in a screw. Yeah, it'll chop up your beans, but you'll quickly get a powder stuck to the bottom under the blade, and then very coarse on top. You can shake it and do a dance with the button, but unless you're going to hold the button down until everything is dust, it's impossible to get a consistent grind throughout.

I am sorry I didn't buy this one the first time! Now that the old one broke, I replace it with this (for the same price), and this one is clearly superior.
As I learned reading reviews of blade grinders: to get the proper vortex, which is what pulls stuff from the top and pushes it from the bottom, creating an even grind, the blade must be turned in opposing directions on either end. This grinder, unlike many others, has the proper blade shape. I noticed the difference immediately.
My old grinder had a 'cable winding' area that didn't actually hold the cable. This one doesn't have a cable storage area, but I really don't care. I've never actually seen a cable storage system that worked in the kitchen. The only one I can think of that works is on my Rowenta iron.

I use this mainly to grind spices like black peppercorns, allspice berries, and dried chilies, etc. My old grinder had the improper blade shape, which left me with chunks of seeds, chilies and such. This grinder grinds it all evenly. And it is the same price as most others. Buy this one if you're not sure.

No difference is coarse or fine grind. No matter what brand or type of coffee is used it all tastes the same. Ugh!
Sorry that I missed the return deadline. Obviously I won't be testing the durability section. Too embarrassed to give this to a thrift shop.

As a newby to the world of freshly-ground, I can wholeheartedly state this is a straight-forward machine that is user-friendly. It does what you want it to do and does it quickly. The length of time you press the grind button determines the size of coffee bean grind. I'm finding very short bursts of grinding gives me the coarseness I want. A good purchase that I would recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good but wish it was easier to clean
reviews.reviewText: This is great for making flax seed meal which is what I use it exclusively for. It grinds the flax seeds super fine very quickly. The only problem I have is cleaning it. Only the plastic top is removable so you have to carefully use a wet paper towel or damp sponge to clean the metal part. This metal part is connected to the motor housing and the instructions are clear not to submerge. It would be nice if the metal grinder part was also removable for better cleaning. Still, the grinder is worth buying. The only reason I am giving it 4 stars is because of the cleaning issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and maintain, coarseness setting doesn't work
reviews.reviewText: I love this coffee machine. Works great. There is a courseness setting that doesn't work. It won't even start grinding on alternative courseness settings. I had purchased another one that I returned for this reason and the new came with the same problem but I kept it. So I would say, if that is an important option for you then purchase a different model. And now I stupidly broke the pot itself. I wish Amazon put links to replacement parts on the same page as the machine itself.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a cheap grinder with no bells or whistles. Buy it with that in mind and you will be happy
reviews.reviewText:
I've bought 3 of the grinders over the years, all for coffee. I'm not into coffee enough to buy a $150 conical burr grinder, I just wanted my daily cup with fresh grinds. This did exactly what I asked of it. My only complaint is likely more my fault than the product, but it's worth noting nonetheless. The plastic head seems to stain easily. That's it. That's my only complaint. None of the electrical has failed me, I've never felt the need to control my grind fineness, and I don't need to brew more than a cup at a time.

If you don't need any fancy bells and whistles, this grinder is likely good enough for you.

I am disappointed with this product. I thought it would be great based on other positive reviews, but it isn't for me.
I was replacing a Hamilton Beach coffee grinder that I loved, but the lid broke so I thought I'd try something different. Mistake. The features it had (for a similar price) were that you could measure the beans right in the coffee grinder and it automatically stoped grinding based on the amount of beans you have. Life was simple with that grinder.
With this KRUPS grinder you have to measure your beans yourself and it takes some calculating because it tells you how much beans per 5 ounces, not per cup. It is messy because you have to turn it upside down to get the grounds out in the cover. It collects moisture around the metal in the bottom, where grounds will stick, even when the grinder seems perfectly dry. It is easy to grind the beans into dust since it is a guess as to how long to grind the beans. It is not convenient to clean because you can't submerge it in water since the lid is the only removable part.
The only positive is that it is very quiet, but considering that it runs for mere seconds, it isn't an important feature for me. I want my noisy Hamilton Beach grinder back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just great for all but the most elite coffee baristas
reviews.reviewText: This is not the quality or consistency of a burr grinder, but for the price and what it is, it works great and for all but the most elite coffee snobs, likely all they really need. Obviously grind control will not be on par with a good burr grinder, so perhaps best where paper filters are used for the brewing (e.g. pour over or drip machine). Unless you happen to get a defective unit, it will likely last you for decades in daily use - as many reviewers have indicated. We use a small brush (solder flux brush available at Home Depot for less than $1 to be exact) to sweep out all the coffee after each use. We now have our old white one reserved for spices, the newer black one is our coffee grinder. At this price, easy to keep two around.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for anyone that lives in small apartments or condos
reviews.reviewText:
Great for anyone that lives in small apartments or condos, but still wants to grind their own coffee beans. Does an excellent job of giving anything from a coarse to a fine grind. Easy to operate. I do have two qualms, however:

1) A lot of the coffee grounds will get stuck below the blade, and have to be removed with a finger, chopstick, etc. As the blade cannot be detached, it has to manually be moved during this process. It's a troublesome and very slightly dangerous process.

2) While the removable lid cleans easily, the blade unit does not. You can probably get away with throwing some water into it, but I don't know how tight the sealing is, so I wouldn't advise it. Using a damp paper towel to wipe the inside down isn't ideal as the paper towel will never pick up 100% of the coffee grounds, but it's the best solution I've come up with thus far.

Despite that, I would purchase this product again, but I'd also be lying if I told you I wasn't interested in purchasing a larger, more convenient unit.

I use this coffee grinder every day. It’s very easy to use and can be used to grind a variety of ingredients. I use it for coffee and oats to make oat flour. It saves me money on buying oat flour, but the capacity is quite small so I have to be careful when opening it after I use it. I also wish that there was a simple setting I could push to make the grounds as coarse or as fine as I need it to be, but at this price, it’s hard to complain about the options for settings.

I grind my beans for 10 seconds for my French press. It’s easy to use and clean and you don’t have to worry about cutting yourself on the blade - very user friendly.

I generally lean towards pre-ground bags when purchasing my own coffee, however I received several bags of beans from Peru, Costa Rica, and the Caribbean as gifts. I'm a big coffee guy, and appreciate changing things up with some freshly ground beans every now and again. Because I knew I would only use it on occasion, I opted not to go with a more expensive model. There are no bells and whistles to speak of. You will find little variation in the consistency of your grinds. This model is best suited for a fine grind. I tend to prefer a medium grind myself, but it does not pose a problem for the cone filters that my Cuisinart requires. If you're patient, a combination of short bursts and shaking the unit in-between can occasionally leave you with a coarse or medium grind, but more often than not I find it's inconsistent and more trouble than it's worth. If run for 5-10 seconds consecutively it creates a metallic scent that is quick to fade, but I have had no issue with the motor giving out. I would either use this unit for coffee or spices, not both. It is not built for an easy clean. Angled shape does help a bit with pouring grinds.

Use it everyday. Works great. Some complaints on here that it doesn’t last. Well, it was less than $20, and if it lasts 6-12 months, I’m fine with that. It is inexpensive enough to just get another. Grinds the beans nice and fine. Cleanup is easy with a dry paper towel to wipe out the inside. Gets the job done.

I use this daily & it takes less than 30 seconds each time to grind up the beans to the coarseness I want (this includes beans for a full pot too). I did research before buying a coffee grinder & this was on the top of many lists, they did not lie and I'm extremely happy with it. When my parents visited & used it, they loved it just as much as they love their grinder & I'm pretty sure if their old one stops working they will buy this one. They were impressed with how quick and relatively quiet it was compared to theirs. Obviously it's loud since it's a grinder, but it is quieter than others I've used before. I haven't used this for anything other than coffee beans but I have no doubt it couldn't chop other things up just as nicely.

reviews.reviewTitle: Effective at blending spices, a bit difficult to clean
reviews.reviewText:
It blended a bunch of different spices very well, including cinnamon sticks (both cassia and ceylon), black peppercorns, cumin, bay leaves, and more. The end result was fairly fine, and I generally did not have any issues with it.

Cleaning is a bit tricky due to its construction, but it isn't too bad. A relative of mine used too much water to clean it and it broke the first one I got, so I ordered a replacement since it was cheap enough.

reviews.reviewTitle: LOVE IT! Really Happy with my purchase.
reviews.reviewText: This is my second one, I bought it to have at my parents house for when I visit a few times a year. My other one I have had for 4 years and it's still going strong! Really happy with my purchase, almost didn't purchase this because of negative reviews, but I really don't know what they're talking about. I have had nothing but luck with this. Makes a good coffee, and it lasts a while.

Pros - easy, grinds well, low noise
Cons - the inside w/ the blades doesn't remove, it's a pain in da butt to try to CAREFULLY clean around blades. So, it's not thorough, unless u dunk it a bit under water. U can't fully submerge it.

Result- RETURNED it...to look for a unit that detaches from the base for easier cleaning & pouring ground coffee into cup.

reviews.reviewTitle: It ground my heart into the ground.
reviews.reviewText:
The first time I used this grinder I used it on oats to make oat flour.. Five seconds later, perfect oat flour. It really does its job and does it well. The only difficult aspect of it is having restraint to run it in a very short burst if you aren't looking for fully pulverized.. For instance, I ground peanuts looking for chunky crunchy peanuts for a Thai salad.. Instead I had peanut flour :(

But that's more about me than the grinder.. I love it. It's not the easiest to clean, I use a damp paper towel to wipe it out because I don't want to get the body wet and there's no way to remove where it grinds which I wish it had. But I can't take away a star for that because this little baby has got real power.

I use this to grind my own spice combinations and it does a wonderful job! It grinds quickly and is MUCH quieter than our Braun coffee grinder of the same basic design, and it cleans up very easily with a damp (not soaking wet) paper towel to remove remaining spice powders. I've also ground some raw rice in it to further clean the blade-cup assembly.

Highly recommend for spice and/or coffee grinding!

reviews.reviewTitle: Reliable grinder for flax seeds (see update)
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this for about six months and I use it regularly to grind flax seeds (to put in yogurt). It does a great job grinding - it produces a very fine powder that mixes perfectly for me. I don't have much of a problem cleaning it; I lightly bang the bottom of the unit on the counter, which frees any clumped powder, and then I wipe it with a wet paper towel.

I would absolutely purchase this product again. I recommend this to you and I hope this review helped you.

Update: For no specific reason, for the last six months I had purchased pre-ground flax seeds. I then I stopped and started using this thing again with regular flax seeds. I was really surprised to find that this unit ground the flax seeds into a much, much finer powder than the stuff that comes pre-ground. This was a nice surprise. I maintain my recommendation and I hope this helps you!

After hours of reading reviews I made my decision. I have also had a krups food processor that has worked flawless for over ten years so I felt pretty confident in the quality. I was right. Though I will not be using this for spices, etc. as I use a mortar and pestle, the coffee grinding is more than sufficient in terms of outcome. Other reviews have stated that you can only get a fine grind with this unit. Not true at all! They simply are not using it correctly. I can grind course, medium or fine after just a little practice. The only reason I left one star out is because when using fresh beans (which are oily) it takes one more step to clean it out so that your next grind doesn't include some stale coffee. Not being fully submersible makes this one more step I wish I didnt have to take. They should include a small brush to clean after each grind. Other than that, it has worked as good as I wanted it to and being a krups product I know I will never have an issue with customer service as they are accomodating even after warrantees have expired. The company itself really stands behind their products and I beleive it is because they have very few problems to deal with.

reviews.reviewTitle: My to go grinder in the kitchen for small quantity ingredients
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to grind spices. It grinds all kinds of spices (including cinnamon sticks) that I tried into powder form. I also use it to grind dried shrimps. East to set up. Grinds into powder form. Easy to wash/clean after each use. This is my go to grinder in the kitchen for small quantity ingredients like spices and dried shrimps. This is more convenient than pulling out that Ninja Grinder and having to wash it very carefully after each use (for small items grinding). The blades are not sharp. So I don't need to worry about cutting myself while washing. Just use a small brush and all things came unsticked/washed off even though you can't remove the blade.

Do not listen to the grind size complainers...This is a good grinder for the money. You just have to get used to how many beans to pour in and how many seconds to grind which for some is too hard lol

I just used it 5 mins ago and have been using the same one everyday for a couple years. Got my moneys worth. Sure a burr grinder is nicer at grinding but 3 times the price of this or more. It's well worth it. Works good! Lasts a long time.

Grinder quit working yesterday. I've had it just over 3 months and have maybe used it 15 times, coffee beans only. Very disappointed! Grind size was fine, took a matter of seconds to grind up beans... Now it just hums, seems motor is locked up... Nice waste of my money...

reviews.reviewTitle: Works alright... while it still works
reviews.reviewText: This review is for the blade grinder (F203) that I purchased just a few months ago, back in June. I barely had used it until I recently got my Aeropress, so at this point I've been using it a few times a week for about a month now. It served it's purpose well until this morning, when the mechanism to power the blade broke while I was grinding some coffee. The blade was stuck spinning without any input so I had to unplug it. Even with the lid off, it spins when plugged into an outlet. Shoddy engineering at it's finest... find a better alternative.

This coffee maker is one of the easiest to clean that I have ever used I use it with paper filters and just have to lightly rinse the basket that holds it the carafe would be better if the lid was easily removable for cleaning though. It brews a very good cup of coffee. The adjustments are straight forward and easy to set. The only things I would change is a larger coffee bean capacity and an easily removable lid on the carafe.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds great but difficult to fill with the beans
reviews.reviewText: It grinds well, my issue with this is how to fill it. It's beyond awkward. I finally figured out to fill the LID with the beans, flop the whole dang thing over and then put it right side up and it can grind the beans that way. To pour beans into the grinder, it is​ a total pain in the butt. It would only grind about half of what its capacity should be able to grind. If there's an easier way, someone please tell me. Because when I fill the reservoir with beans, I can't fit the lid on....because the beans are in the way and the lid won't latch down in there correctly. SO I do it upside down, flip it and grind them then.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beware of parts service and availability!
reviews.reviewText: I happily used the Krups KM785D50 for a month after receipt, it made excellent coffee. However, one day when emptying the filter basket, the spring loaded valve mechanism came apart in my hand. I contacted Krups on their website explaining the problem. They answered promptly referring me to two different parts supply businesses, where I could BUY a new filter basket. Only one of the two companies listed my model number, so I ordered 2 baskets (being prepared for the future!) with same day shipping included. After that I heard nothing. After a week I contacted the parts company and was told that this filter basket was sold out nationally, and a new shipment was expected a month and a half from now! Considering the poor reliability of this part, I fully understand why it was sold out, but I consider the apparent lack of concern - both by Krups and the parts dealer - to be rather shoddy! And I can only hope that new baskets will include a better design.

We love this grinder. My mother has one that she uses for coffee and I needed one to grind eggshells to use in our cats/dogs raw meat diet when their meat doesn't have enough bone. This is the best grinder we've used and I'll definitely buy it again when our existing coffee grinder dies (it's another brand). It's quiet, grinds to a very fine powder if you wish and also grinds a larger amount than our other brand. For the money, I think this is the best grinder you can find. Other reviewers also remarked that it lasts a long time - another big plus.

Got this and Peets coffee beans for christmas. Peets beans are GREAT! So is the grinder. It's easy to use and easy to listen to hear when the larger chunks are gone. It is kind of loud which is hilarious because I get to watch my 3 cats scatter! As for cleaning, I use a wet paper towel, with or without a little soap and clean thoroughly.
I read someone used a paintbrush...that sounds like a great idea and I'll try that too.

Works great. I love it. My old one lasted about 3 or 4 years, but I had ground various spices (mustard seed, cumin seed, allspice, cardamom, etc.) in it and washed it out afterwards which may have contributed to the blade finally sticking fast, which I didn't notice and tried to use, which at last burnt out the motor, I think. You can't immerse the bottom but I used a wet rag to wipe it out after grinding the different spices; then air dry. And for coffee, maybe 15 or 20 seconds of pressing on the little button on top and your beans are fully ground. A little longer and you've got espresso grind.

Just plug it in and it zooms to grind anything. TIP: Flip it upside down when you are done and with the lid still on give it one last whiz, it will end up in the lid and no need to touch the blades. Easy clean up too, just add a few grains of rice and it absorbs all the grease, and liquid, from whatever you ground before. Don't forget to hold that upside down too. Blades are sharp.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far . . . it does the job well.
reviews.reviewText: So far so good. I had a white one for 30+ years, used at least daily every day and sometimes more, that bit the dust. I replaced it with a different brand that worked well initially, then didn't, then just not acceptable at all. I replaced it with the Krups I had purchased about 20+ years ago for spices only. It's working beautifully every day and occasionally more than once. Couldn't be more pleased. However, I now needed to replace my spice grinder so I bought this one for that purpose.
